Great food, cozy atmosphere, The Wine advise was a little too focussed on the staffs taste. I would come again but there were a few strange things, we tried to make a reservation, and they acted as if it wod be really difficult. When we arrived there were barely any people anymore. :S 
Other than that:
Excellent service by the wonderful Renata!!!!!!!!
author: Yuri B.

description:
Ok, so after some silly reviews of lesser places in SF, I get serious again for Frascati. Simply put...I do this because Frascati was VERY serious with me.

First, as per usual for me, the wine list. Stunning, though not massive, selection of wines. From their California highlights...to the REAL deal French reds, this is a wine list perfectly suited to the simple and elegant fare on offer here.

On my first visit, we chose a lovely '06 Cotes du Rhone from the famed producers of legendary Chateauneuf offerings, Rayas. Perfect.

Perfect with what?

Starters: heirloom tomatoes with burrata (simple, perfectly plated, beautiful to see), beef carpaccio (nice size with the most amazingly appropriate crunch capers).

The bottle lasted (somehow...) through the main course...and both of us chose the roasted chicken. Heavenly (and simply) served with potatoes and a bit of spinach. Grabbed a side of perfectly charred brussel sprouts...and all was right with the world.

The ambiance is as simple (and perfect) as the food. It didn't help that my companion was brilliant and drove great conversation...next, I'll head back to see if a silent two hours adds or takes away from the amazingly straight-forward and perfectly prepared food at Frascati.

Be prepared for a little sticker shock...and if you aren't ready to pay for this level of perfection...then don't seek it.
author: Bo S.

description:
Let me tell you about this little restaurant, Frascati. 
You barely squeeze your way through this tiny, congested doorway as parties are trying to exit at the same time. It is jam packed, dim, and fairly loud for such a tiny place; a fire hazard for sure. You can't even focus on what you're doing as you're trying to take in everything that's going on around you all at once. Then, suddenly, in slow motion all the noise and bustling of people dissipate as a PHAT, fully loaded, grilled pork chop passes right in front of you, trailing behind it's sweet succulent aroma of red meat with a hint of apple and bacon. Just from the smell alone you can tell how juicy and tender the chop is. As you warp back to reality all that's on your mind is pork chop, pork chop, pork chop.

Good thing we had reservations because we got seated fairly quickly. To start, we had the veal carpaccio. Words cannot describe how melt in your mouth, finger licking, delicious this appetizer was. For being my first time having carpaccio, I am fairly certain this place has destroyed my chances of enjoying any other carpaccio dish elsewhere. It has spoiled my taste buds forever.

For my main dish, I obviously had the grilled pork chop, and of course it was the best I ever had. Surpassed my expectations with flying colors. So good there is no such thing as hyping it up. My friend had the fresh fettuccini with shrimp, clams, mussels, and calamari in an amazing basil pesto and citrus gremolata. I had a couple bites and it was to die for. Secretly I wanted to steal it and eat it all, but some how managed to keep my composure and control myself. Had to be dainty and lady like, you know? This was a nice restaurant!

After all that and a nice bottle of Malbec, we had no room for dessert. Everybody there was kind and helpful. Even with the place so unbelievably busy, the service was excellent. They knew when to come to our aid and when to give us some space. ..Or maybe I was a bit too tipsy to even have cared o.O

I will forever rave about this place and plan on coming again and again (well maybe not too often since it is quite expensive). I love it!!
author: Jeanne K.

description:
This is a neighborhood restaurant that we have been meaning to try for the past two years. We had heard great things from friends who also live in the area, and we knew we needed to try it since we're moving soon and wanted to determine whether it's worth the trip. 

Unfortunately, I don't think we'll be back. We had a reservation for four on a Friday, and the table they gave us was next to the stairs and close to the bathrooms - which I could smell during the entire meal! Not bad bathroom smell, but bathroom smell nonetheless. It was very uncomfortable.

While the food was decent (we had two orders of the chicken, and two orders of the fish dish, as well as some uneventful appetizers), the service put a real damper on things. First we waited a good fifteen minutes for someone to even take our drink order. After waiting another ten minutes, only half the drinks arrived. We still hadn't had a chance to ask questions about the menu, and had no bread or butter to pick at.

The waitress may have been overextended that night, but she gave us really icky attitude - sort of a cross between passive-aggressive and phony niceness. We felt rushed, ignored, and frustrated until the entrees arrived (we were entertaining guests from England). The meal was very expensive, mainly because of the alcohol (total of five glasses, plus one beer).

Despite the horrible service (which was really, really horrible), the food was ok, so I would recommend this place perhaps on a weeknight, if no other place is available, and you make sure not to sit near the bathroom.
author: Cynthia S.

description: Recommended by the concierge at the Ritz,  was fabulous. A little noisy, but an authentic Italian bistro. The salads were fabulous, the brown butter sage pork ravioli was fabulous, everything was fantastic. This would be our regular intimate bistro place if we lived there. Will Definitely return.
author: Duchess M.

description:
My favorite San Francisco restaurant (so far...)

My Mother and I enjoyed a meal with pitch perfect ambiance, wine (chardonnay and pino noir), roasted pear salad, pork chop for my Mom, and branzino for me. Finished with a divine affagato and panna cotta.

My mother and I loved sharing the pear salad, it was something else! My mother said the pork chop was the best she had ever had. My branzino skin was flavorful and tasty, I feel sad for anyone who was not daring enough to eat it with the skin on!


One Thing!  The affagato should have chocolate drizzled of the rim of the glass and a spoon dipped in chocolate in order to be perfect.

O, and one other thing, the wine was divine, but how about a cocktail list? Then Frascati would be perfect.
author: Natalie J.

description: The ambiance in this restaurant is so comfortable and romantic, it's perfect for a date night. We got sardines, gnocchi, lamb risotto, and filet mignon. Everything was fantastic. The wine was good too. I look forward to coming back!
author: Brianna C.

description:
Went here with 2 of my girlfriends excited to try this place, but it just didn't cut it for me. May just be that I don't seem to like American food though. 

We ordered: 
The Maple Leaf Duck Breast
Pork Chops 
Halibut 

The duck breast was by far the best, which is why this rating is getting 3 stars and not 2. My pork chops and the halibut were just okay. They were bland and lacking in flavor. Unfortunately because we didn't like our meal so much, we skipped dessert and I didn't get to try the bread pudding, and I doubt I ever will. Won't be planning to come here again any time soon.
author: Alisa C.

description:
I busted out my 2001 Brunello di Montalcino La Togato Riserva for dinner. I was saving this wine since my trip to Montalcino, Italy 4 years ago. Oh this dinner will be a memorable meal!!!  

I started with the butternut squash gnocchi based on the waiter's recommendation. It was good but when the sardines were served in the table next to ours I was wishing I had ordered the sardines instead. For the main I got the Maple Leaf Duck Breast. It was perfect. Medium rare. The waiter suggested venison but I tend to not like leaner meat. I ordered a side to get brussel sprouts. Don't ask me why. I have tried brussel sprouts several times and everytime...gag reflex. It's just so bitter. Well, it was all good because I had my Brunello to wash it all down ;-)

The desserts looked deeelish and I would have ordered something if I hadn't just baked a ginormous chocolate devil food layer cake at home. I didn't bring it with though because of the $3/person cutting fee. Corkage was $20 which isn't great but I've seen worse. 

Cute little restaurant, awesome meal. I'll be coming back.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Definitely a disappointment.  Especially for the price, the food was sub-par, and average at best.  We ordered an appetizer of foie gras. It turned out to be a patte (I must have misread the menu, as I was looking forward to a grilled piece) and combined with the choice and texture of the bread it was served with, the dish did not impress. The service was fine, definitely just fine.  One of the staff members was oblivious to the fact that him standing above our table and carrying on a loud conversation with the table next to us, made it hard for us to hear ourselves talk.  And, unfortunately his ass, while being at eye level to me for at least twenty minutes, wasn't much of a pleasant distraction [yes, that would have made at least more bearable ;-)].

With dinner, they provided salad / appetizer size forks. I don't know, I kind of like a fork to extend beyond my palm, rather than jamming into my palm, when cutting into a slab of meat.    When I asked about this, I was told that they were a bistro and not gary danko.  When did being provided with a properly sized fork (with a meat bearing entree, too boot) become contingent on the "fine dining" rating of the restaurant? Next...
author: N F.

description: We'd give Frascati 3.5 stars. Came here for our anniversary dinner last night and based on the previous reviews we were expecting to be blown away. We were not. It was generally pretty good - the burrata appetizer, duck breast and chocolate bread pudding were the standouts, but the pasta dish was just good and the soup lacked flavor. The thing that turned us off the most was our server. She was efficient, but not very attentive, and she seemed to be in a bad mood. Every time we asked for something or placed an order she was abrupt and never smiled. We tried to be extra pleasant with her but to no avail. In any event, we thought it was ok but definitely wasn't good enough to compel us to travel that far and deal with gruesome parking (the Walgreen's lot on Polk & Broadway is your best bet) when there is way better choices in the the Mission, SOMA and The Castro.
author: Scott G.

description:
I had a birthday dinner here last night.  I selected this place because it was so highly reviewed on yelp.

The food was AMAZING.  We had almost all of the starters but the ones I liked most were the fig bruschetta dish (don't remember exactly what it was called) and the burrata caprese (although, I've never met a burrata I didn't like).  Oh, wait, I can't forget the cheese plate.  I've eaten many cheese plates but this one introduced me to new pairings - I was impressed.

The entrees were just as delicious.  We ordered the duck, the chicken, the flat iron steak and the pork sugo pasta.  They were all super delicious but the two that stand out were the roasted chicken (which was SO tender and flavorful) and the pasta, which I asked for HOT (and was pleasantly surprised to find it so).  The pork sugo was just as tender and plentiful as the half chicken dish and was complemented with fresh pasta ribbons.  The fresh pasta was nice, but I'd have eaten the pork on toast.  haha!

We brought our own dessert (as it was my birthday) so I can't say anything about their sweets.  I'm sure they're just as mouthwatering as the rest of their menu, though.

I DID NOT GIVE THEM 5 STARS because they sat us in the loft, directly above the kitchen/stove.  The restaurant is basically a house converted into a restaurant, which is fine if you're seated on the bottom level (or maybe even in the upstairs back room).  Our table was NOT and so within a half hour of our arrival, we were all developing a nice shiny glow to our skin (mostly apparent in our reddening faces).  We took our time with our food and were probably there for 3 hours (maybe 3.5 hrs).  By the end of the evening, we had sweated out of our clothes and smelled like we had dined in a fish & chips joint - no shit.  I've gotta clean and dry clean everything I brought in there.

So, in conclusion, I definitely suggest you give them a try, just insist on a downstairs table.
author: erica c.

description: This was our first time at this GREAT restaurant. The host Justin was very accommodating and knowledgeable about wine. We shared the Beretta appetizer and the my wife had the duck con fit salad and I had the bread salad, both great, but hers was outstanding. She then had the chicken and I had the maple  duck breast, again both great, but my duck was one of the very best I have ever had. Finished with my wife having the bread pudding and I had the espresso coffee ice cream.  If they could only figure out parking. Highly recommend this outstanding restaurant to anyone.
author: Bob E.

description:
On our trip to San Francisco we wanted to try something a little off the beaten path- to maybe for a chance, feel like locals and not like a tourist on fisherman's wharf. Well I'm so happy we found Frascati on yelp :)

Maybe I'm biased because we got to reunited with old friends- but this was my favorite part of our whole trip. Tucked away in the Russian Hilll this restaurant was nothing but charm. We had the most wonderful dinner with our friends. Our table was in my opinion, the best in the house- tucked into the window nook with a great view of the trolley coming up and down the hill. We were informed that Jennifer Aniston once ate in that exact spot. not that this is really important to me- but good to know?

Our waitress was friendly and helpful in picking dishes- you got the impression that she has eaten everything on the menu- which i think is important. She also was helpful in selecting wines to match our dishes. By the way, the wines by the glass selection was great! The food was simple yet delicious, well executed dishes. The mushroom bruschetta stands out in my mind, as does the branzino. YUM.

But good luck finding parking in under 10 minutes- and if you aren't a local- good luck parallel parking on that hill!
author: Erika G.

description:
This place is great, the people are friendly and the food is great! The only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is because the starters completley outweighed the entrees AND they knew it was my husband's 30th birthday and I was a little bummed they didn't give a free dessert...but the dessert was delicious...

Resturaunt: located on the corner of Hyde Street, first apperance is like a cute little cafe in Paris.  Strung with pretty lights, there a few tables are located outside and are up against the resturaunts large window front so you can peak inside while still enjoying the fresh air. The place is small, i guess it was originally house so it almost feels like you are eating at your own home but with cute tables and great ambiance. 

We were seated upstairs right next to a large window that overlooked the streets. I am so glad that we sat near the window because it was SO HOT upstairs. The upstairs section is located right above the kitchen so it got extremely warm.

Food: We ordered a bottle of red Lambrusco which was delicious and was a great price. We heard great things about the cheese plate so we will have to try that next time. We started off with Russet Potatoe Gnocci and the Grilled Bread Salad. The Gnocci was BY FAR the best thing we had all night. great flavor and textures. yum! my husband had the pork chop which he said was very delicious and he finished the whole thing and I had the rissoto with clams, shrimp and mussels. I was pleasantly surprised that this didn't have a strong fish flavor. i could pick up indiviudals flavors which and it was very creamy. We had the black and white bread pudding which caramel sauce and hazelnut ice cream! SO amazing! i would absolutely recommend it!

Service: I have to say the overall service was amazing. I had mentioned once that it was my husband 30th birthday and when we walked up they wished him a happy birthday and made sure to put a candle on the bread pudding when they brought it out. Very sweet.

Overall experience was great. We will be going back for the appetizers and desserts :)
author: Whitney S.

description: Boyfriend took me here for my birthday dinner. Cute little restaurant with a really cozy atmosphere-not too prestigious. Great wine selections. Our server Gabby was really awesome and an asset to the restaurant. We started off with the cheese plate. I'm celiac so that means super allergic to anything containing wheat/ barley. Asked if they had any gluten free bread or crackers. They didn't but I asked for extra apple slices and they were glad to accommodate and Gabby also made a note on our order so the kitchen knew of my allergy. The cheese plate was a generous size with some dried apricots and figs and almonds and honey too. Really delicious. Next we split the butter lettuce salad but subbed vinaigrette for the creamy dressing that normally comes on it. So good! For our main course I got the filet mignon and my bf got the pork chop. My steak was cooked perfectly and everything was served piping hot. Both dishes were generous portions, packed with flavor and delicious. The prices in general were really reasonable for the city. Gabby brought out some house made ice cream with a candle for my bday. The ice cream was some of the best I've ever had, no joke. Shoutout to our server Gabby and Frascati for giving us such a wonderful experience. We will definitely be recommending the place to our friends and we will be back!
author: Lil M.

description: Magical warm Friday night in SF we walked over without reservations and we were seated outside.  The food was AMAZING.  We had the bread salad to start and my husband had the roasted chicken and I had the kale risotto.  Finished the meal with the cobbler. Still thinking about the meal and how good it was - excellent service as well --we will definitely return!
author: L W.

description:
I picked this place (and many of the dishes) based on the strong yelp reviews of late, and once again yelp was right. 

Every dish we ordered was excellent, with the highlights being the grilled octopus salad, seafood risotto, and of course the chocolate bread pudding. The grilled bread salad, duck, and monkfish were also excellent, but I'd put them one level below those above (probably based on personal taste more than anything else). 

The place feels like the neighborhood gem type, and the service was very friendly and knowledgeable, albeit slightly on the slow side.
author: Louis D.

description: The food was top notch. Had the duck and it was perfect. Sweet corn bisque was excellent. And the staff was top notch. Would highly recommend
author: Dave B.

description:
Updated 12/17/06:
The duck breast was overcooked and disappointing on my second visit. Changing my rating to 3 stars from 4.

Initial Review:
Frascati is a serious player in the San Francisco dining scene. The mussels and chorizo were a nice start, but the highlight was the maple leaf duck breast; delicious.

We were able to get a table on Thursday night about half an hour beforehand. The restaurant was busy, but not overwhelmed. Service was reasonable, though our waiter grew flaky towards the end of our meal. He took away my wine glass without asking and it wasn't empty (major party foul, dude).

The ambiance is date-worthy, and there is a nice European feel to the space. After dinner change scenery to Bacchus (if there is room) where the wine flows like beer...
author: Jeremy S.

description:
This place is amazing! Took my partner here for his birthday and we absolutely loved the food and the wonderful service. I highly recommend the maple duck, the filet mignon, the gnocchi appetizer and the peach and blueberry cobbler! Every piece of food we received on our table tonight was cooked perfectly. My partner -- who is incredibly hard to please -- said that the filet mignon was the best food he's ever tasted. Also, the waitress that we had (Coni) was really superb! She's funny and perceptive about our needs as customers. She even brought out a little candle for our birthday dessert. So glad we came here. We will be back again! 

NOTE: If you plan to come here, ride the train, bus, taxi, uber or lyft. Finding parking was incredibly difficult. We parked 18 mins away from the restaurant -- and this is on a Monday evening. Totally worth it though because the food was flawless.
author: Carla B.

description:
Pretty & bustling space.. we were seated upstairs, which we actually liked - a bit quieter.
Terrific service - good recommendations on wine - service was very attentive but not ridiculous. I wish she had been a bit more biased about the menu - i worry a bit when everything is good - it's not but in general things are quite good here - with some stand-outs. Loved squid salad. Duck salad not as delicious but good. Burrata appetizer delcious. Mushroom bruscetta was yummy in a made at home kind of way - but it is bruscetta so that's expected.
Note to non meat eaters - there are meat products in a number of things that at a glance appear meat free so if you are concerned read closely and ask.
Lots of different dishes at the table all general quite good and sufficient quantity.
Sadly they were out of panna cotta. Wah!
Now - about parking - it is horrible so leave 30 minutes and hope if you are coming on any evening. I'd skip weekends if you have to drive - it's not worth the frustration and will seriously taint your dining experience.
Worth it if it's easy to get there - after that it's a balance of parking zen and curiosity.
author: Jennifer e.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF. Have been twice and each time has really been a great experience the entire way through the meal. Burrata, pork chop, and chicken stand out in my mind...as does the Pinot Noir. It's got a romatic/classy vibe to it - but you can still go casual. The place is always busy but we have walked in with a very short wait during the Friday-night peak.
author: Sean S.

description:
Sometimes the best things in life are entirely unexpected and unplanned.  Such was my experience at Frascati.  

On an ordinary Sunday evening, I began surfing the web for restaurants to try on a whim.  I stumbled across Frascati, which sounded interesting, so I thought, why not give it a try?  After all, it was a beautiful evening in the city, and I decided that I might as well make the most of it before diving into a new work week.  Little did I know I was about to discover one of my favorite restaurants.

Frascati is located in Russian Hill in a quaint and picturesque neighborhood, which merely adds to its charm.  The inside of the restaurant is small and warm, and has two levels for seating.  I was fortunate to be seated on the top level near the railing, giving us a view of the restaurant below and the street outside, where a traditional San Francisco trolley would occasionally roll down the street.

Shortly after being seated, our waiter stopped by our table I asked for suggestions on a glass of wine to start.  I was looking for a buttery Chardonnay, and the waiter recommended what turned out to be an excellent, creamy, buttery, and smooth glass of wine.  The dinner was off to a good start.  Next I had the Grilled Bread Salad.  The salad was large, full of fresh ingredients, delicious feta cheese, and was covered in a delicate champagne vinaigrette.  For my main dish I ordered the rack of lamb and I think that this is the best rack of lamb that I have ever had.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly (and was also nicely complemented by my second glass of wine, again recommended by the waiter).  Finally, for dessert I had the bread pudding.  And this was one of the best bread puddings that I have ever had - so warm, buttery and comforting...I wish that I was eating it right now.

So while not every impulsive decision is rewarding, this one was, and I highly recommend Frascati.

Disclaimer:  This review is based on my experience at Frascati about 18 months ago.  I presume that the quality has not changed.
author: David S.

description:
This is my favorite romantic place to eat in San Francisco.   I love it.

The food is amazing and the location is as charming as can be.

I really think it's SF's best option in the "$$$" price range.  It's not inexpensive in anyway, but to get anything better you have have to spend a *lot* more.  Like Gary Danko expensive.

If you take your significant other to Frascati, you will have one very happy significant other!
author: William J.

description:
I proposed to my fiancee and chose Frascati as the restaurant we would go to celebrate afterwards. Now, I know the description says it's not good for groups, but we wanted our families there. I made reservations 2 weeks before and it was the Golden Gate's 75th Anniversary date, so I expected it to be difficult for them to accommodate a GROUP OF EIGHTEEN PEOPLE!!!! But they did it NO PROBLEM. They didn't give us attitude, they sat us promptly, they had everything ready, and made the night really special. The ambiance is intimate and small. It's classy and upscale. The server was very attentive and had excellent manners. This is a classic SF restaurant in a classic SF neighborhood. We took a cab up to the restaurant, it is extremely difficult to find parking though, and it is almost impossible to walk to it because of the steep roads. The cable car rides right past the Restaurant too. I will say though that their bathroom is extremely small, beware all who are claustrophobic! But all in all great place.

 I had the duck and the cheese platter and they were to die for! They were beautifully presented and had nice garnashings. The price is what I expected for a romantic dinner, and a special occasion, and they DIDN'T dissapoint! We also had the chocolate pudding desert, it was exquisite. 

Frascati is the real deal folks.
author: Angel M.

description:
A lot of fun.  A casual, warm place with a good selection of wine; not pretentious.  Really enjoyed the octopus salad; it was the standout dish of the night.  The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable.

I'd be happy to eat here the next time I am back in the Bay.
author: R S.

description:
I prefer the local, higher quality, quaint, smaller restaurants and this fits the bill!  Amazing service (not interrupting the table but always available), busy with a nice amount of space between the tables (not too far apart but not too close), and the food quality was amazing.  We truly enjoyed our evening and the ambiance.  We had the hotel car drop us off an pick us up so I can not comment on the parking.

Loved it and would visit again.
author: Chris J.

description:
Russian Hill is one of those neighborhoods that I rarely frequent, but when I do, I'm struck by the neighborhood feel. Frascati is one of those neighborhood places that is cozy and comforting. 

On a recent late fall evening, a round of Brussels sprouts, gnocchi and beet salad were the perfect accompaniments to a crisp, borderline SF cold night. 

We lucked out and got the best seat in the house in the corner window. If you go, be sure to request that coveted window seat and sit back and take in the glorious neighborhood that is Russian Hill.
author: Lee H.

description:
We wandered into here randomly for dinner, because the place we originally wanted to go to had an hour long wait. I'm glad we did, this place was great! This restaurant is located in a cute little neighborhood and was nestled off a main street. Even though cable cars would pass by occasionally it wasn't noisy on this street. 

This place wasn't busy when we got there at 6:30 on a Saturday night, but shortly afterward around 7pm it got packed. The ambiance was great, very romantic if that's what you're looking for. Service was amazing, wait staff would check on us often. The food was great, I had the pappardelle noodles, which was fantastic! Tom cat had pork chops and consumed every bit of it. They also had a nice wine selection. I would definitely come back to Frascati's the next time I'm visiting SF.
author: Marilyn V.

description: Very nice menu and atmosphere. Roasted Chicken is the specialty of the house.
author: Peter L.

description:
Food was okay.  We had the foie gras...but it reminded us more of a tureen...you know the pureed salmon or whatever you use?  Yeah, that would be the consistency.  And the salad, was barely seasoned with dressing or anything else.  Ick.

I had the duck breast, and it was overly cooked on one side, and rare on the other.  So...it was dry and barely edible on the top and soft and juicy on the bottom, and worthless.  He had the lamb shank, which he found to be very unremarkable.  

We had the Mantra (05 Zin) old vines, and it wasn't what we'd expected. 

Service was pretentious.  Very much so, which matched their other patrons.  :-(
Staff was a bit pushy!
Wine/beer list was okay.
Cozy and nice ambience.
Parking was an utter pain.  
It was an okay dinner for a special occasion, but you know what...
Boulevard is hard to top! :-)

Disappointment.  Just not for us!
author: Fannie S.

description:
Well, assuming this review doesn't get filtered like my other ones, here we go:

Came here on a first date. Interesting location in Nob Hill. Decor was fine, not pretentious but I found it a little underwhelming. Sat for dinner at about 7pm on a Tuesday. It was not very crowded but a little later, probably around 8pm it got pretty full. 

The service was excellent. Wait staff was always there but not in your face or overbearing. Food was pretty good. We split the Gnocchi starter. It was very tasty. For the second course I ordered the duck confit salad and she ordered the octopus salad. The duck salad was very good. For the main entree I ordered the italian sausage risotto. It was very flavorful. The dish exploded flavor that seemed to be infused throughout it, while there wasn't much discernible sausage to be seen by the naked eye.

We also ordered a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc, a Sancerre. The wine was very good and my date and I also ordered one more glass after the bottle. We skipped desert.

Everything was very good, and I was pleased overall. That being said, the final bill for two people for dinner and a bottle of wine was $200 including tip. I could spend that on a date at a recognized 5 star fine dining establishment, like a Capital Grille or Morton's etc. A bit pricey for what you get, but no compaints overall. I would give 3.5 - 3.75 stars if possible, but I'll err on the positive side.
author: Neal F.

description: What a wonderful experience! A friend took me for my birthday and I had the best time. The meal was absolutely delicious, duck sausage pasta was amazing as was the bread salad and the warm chocolate bread pudding. The service was the best I've had in a long time. I can't wait to go back!
author: Roy K.

description:
This is another San Francisco gem.

This is among my very favorite places to bring either a date or people visiting from outside San Francisco.   This is a top ten in San Francisco place.

The food is excellent.  Certain perennial menu favorites rightfully endure and yet there's always something fresh as well.  Service is among the very best in the city, polite, efficient, unobtrusive and knowledgeable.  The portions are not 'american' huge and are beautifully presented but not three dimensional food which has to be disassembled to be eaten pretentious.  The place is a bit loud when crowded, but I'm more noise sensitive than most.  At it most crowded its never too loud to carry on a conversation.  It is also an absolutely beautiful, aesthetic, charming little neighborhood restaurant.  They do not cater to the tourist trade.  This is a locals only place.

This is one of those places that I only rarely told anyone about for years.   Its, that, good.

If you're not a drinker, two people can get out of here for $50-$60.  The wine list is compact, diverse, and if you know some of the local wines, there are, or at least used to be, some genuine bargains.

You can, and I have brought out-of-towners here via a cable car, which runs right in front of the place on Hyde, and hop off twenty feet from the front door.   It makes for a very memorable San Francisco experience, particularly on a foggy night.  Even if you cab it, highly advisable, whoever you bring here will remember the place.  Its right on Hyde in Russian Hill proper.  Parking, even by San Francisco standards is in a word, a nightmare.

My mother, the foodie still talks about this place, not Gary Danko, not La Folie, not Massa's, this place and Boulevard is what she talks about.  People always remember this place.

This place is totally off the tourist track in mid-Russian hill.  I discovered this place many years ago when I lived on Nob Hill.  Love it, still love it.

Go there.
author: Michael C.

description:
This year is the second time I celebrated my birthday there with a party of 5.

Rating of 4.5 stars due to excellent food with friendly service.  This time we brought our own very very special wines but otherwise their wine list is terrific.

Wild mushroom bruschetta + beef carpaccio - excellent 
I've had duck 2x now - so tasty & tender you don't even need a steak knife
Grilled ribeye - blew everybody away and paired very well with our 2000 cab.
Black cod and pork chop - my friends didn't leave a bite left.
Sadly I don't quite remember which desserts we've gotten but all quite tasty and eaten to the last bite.

The only downside is that it's small so tables are cramped.  Plus they're quite busy so service can be a bit slow.  But if you're there with enjoyable company, you won't mind so much.  

And one request to Frascati - can you change your website so that your menus can be pulled up right away without listening to the music and intro?  =)  Please?
author: FoodieGal I.

description:
Don't  let the 4 stars fool you, I really did love this place.  It wasn't perfect, though and I reserve 5 stars for perfection.  This neighborhood gem has great atmosphere and the impecable wait staff was very friendly and helpful.  

Here's what we ordered:
Russet Potato Gnocchi with Melted Leeks, Butternut Squash, Black Trumpet Mushrooms, Parmesan and White Truffle Oil - this was a terrific dish, but the butternut squash was a bit undercooked and we actually mistook it for carrots b/c it was so crunchy.  

Grilled pear salad....little "mellon balls" of grilled pear and acorn squash, dried cranberries, goat cheese, spiced pecans, all drizzled with tarragon vinaigrette - definitely their standout dish.  This was one of the best salads I've had.

Maple Leaf Duck Breast with Herb Spaetzle, Hearts of Palm Salad, Wild Arugula, Scallions and Huckleberry Sauce - the duck was a bit overcooked, but the herb spaetzle was to die for.  Terrific sauce and combination of flavors.  If the duck were cooked better, it would have been outstanding.

I also ordered the halibut, but I can't remember everything in the dish and it wasn't listed on their website.  I remember it was supposed to have parsnip puree.  This dish was definitely lacking and bland.  I cook halibut at home and there's a lot of potential with this fish - unfortunately, they didn't deliver.  Hopefully they'll mix up this recipe and swap it for something else.

We ordered the chocolate bread pudding b/c we heard so much fuss about it.  It was just ok and we didn't flip over it.  Maybe it was b/c there was coconut in it and neither of us are coconut fans.  It was well prepared, though, and the hazelnut ice-cream was a nice touch.

Overall great experience and very happy we tried it.  I'll be trying other restaurants on my list before going back to this one, though.
author: Alison E.

description:
Delicious. Had the steak with blue cheese/tomatoes. Cooked to perfection. The only thing that wasn't 5 stars was the cheese plate appetizer-- skip it. 

From Chicago-- a huge foodie town-- and super impressed with Frascati. Go try it!
author: Katie F.

description:
I had the great fortune of living within a few blocks of this fantastic restaurant for 17 years.  I also had the misfortune of not being part of the SF wealthy elite.... So I didn't get to eat here as often as I would have liked (um - every day).  That is not to say that it is extremely expensive, but for my budget it was a 'special occasion' restaurant.  In our last several years in the City, my wife and I would go here for almost all of our celebratory meals, raises, promotions, anniversaries, holidays, Thursdays...  Occasionally we would be overcome with a need to try one of the many other places the City had to offer... sure enough - next occasion... back to Frascati!!

I ate here many, many times over the years and never had a bad meal.  In fact it was almost always a perfect dining experience.  Friendly, helpful, knowledgeable, courteous staff.  Wonderful atmosphere.  Fantastic food.

Frascati is located on Russian Hill along a very quaint stretch of Hyde Street, with the cable car running by... it is a cozy place that is relaxed, but also elegant.  Great for date night or dinner with friends or family.  There is also a nice loft area upstairs that offers additional seating from the main floor dining area, and overlooks the main cooking area.  One of the two tables in the front windows is a great place to sit if you can manage to get one.

The staff makes you feel welcome from the moment you call to make a reservation.  (This is a place that actually calls you back if you leave a message during the day to make a reservation.)  Once you arrive, the excellent service continues throughout your evening.  They are very attentive without hovering.  There have been times where we had three or four different individuals stop by the table just to make sure everything was OK, and see how we were enjoying everything.  The waiters are very knowledgeable when asked about various items on the menu, and also very adept at recommending quality wines (not just the most expensive) from their wine list.  We often would take our own bottle of wine, and we never received the attitude that you sometimes get when bringing your own bottle.  They were happy to open and often decant our wine for us.

The food... Well, I don't have the time or the writing expertise to properly relay how glorious the food is.  You've seen several reviews mentioning the gnocchi... they are not to be missed!  Everything here is fabulous!  Typical meal:  Appetizer, salad, entrée, and finish with the cheese course... Unfortunately, this usually means we are too stuffed to try the desserts - but on the occasions where I've managed... they have also been great.

Risotto, Pork Chops, and Duck Breast - Oh my!  Frascati we miss you!  But we'll be back soon!

I don't give out five stars easily... How many five star ratings have I given to restaurants?
author: Darren R.

description:
Loved this place. My boyfriend and I wanted to have a nice Italian dinner before a concert, so we made a reservation at Frascati. The food was top-notch. We started with the cheese platter and gnocchi - both highly recommended. I had the porkchop. I'm not usually into pork, but the menu description sounded so great that I just had to try it. The pork was perfectly moist and the glaze was the perfect mix of sweet and salty. My boyfriend had the scallops, which melted in your mouth.
We ended with the apple cobbler and ice cream - very standard, but A+. The cobbler was hot and fresh out of the oven. 

The service was superb. The wait staff seemed really enjoy their jobs, and were very knowledgeable about their foods. I also got the sense that the owner(s?) had a sense of humor - there was a note at the bottom of the menu that all cell phones in use would be confiscated and made into soup. There was also a category of drinks in the dessert menu called "Potent Potables" (YAY). 

The restaurant itself was adorable, too. Perfect for a date night, or just an intimate dinner with a few friends.
author: Jane H.

description: Simply amazing food, service and a cute, cozy ambiance. I can't wait to go back.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
After five years of living three blocks away I finally made it to Frascati! I was so excited to have finally gone here since each time I pass by I think..."Why haven't I gone here, yet? I'll go someday" and then weeks, months and years pass by.  I decided that this would be the perfect date spot on a Friday night and dined there this past week. 

I wanted to love this place. I wanted to fall in love at, in and with this place.  I felt that our meal was quite good: torchon, pasta, pork chops and bread pudding. The wine was solid.  However, after five years of living here and eating at alot of SF restaurants I felt that this place was above average.  It didn't wow me but made me realize how its a consistent, steady selection for a weekend date place.  

I will definitely be back since the service was excellent, the atmosphere was romantic and the lighting was perfect.
author: Sarah C.

description: Love this place excellent service, friendly staff ,wonderfully prepared food .The duck breast was my favorite meal that I had in the two weeks I was in San Francisco.
author: Greg B.

description:
Without a doubt - I'd stand behind every one of the five stars I'm rating this place. Great service, atmosphere, location, variety of selection, and TASTE. Wow. I was suitably blown away bit by bit as we were served dish after dish. 

The roasted potato gnocchi appetizer was tasteful, without being overpowering - mild cheese flavors mixed with bits of leek and diced squash for a tasty flavorful mix. Mochi loved his black cod crusted with almond main, and I was raving within my first bite into the delicious pork chop. It was pretty much the best pork chop I've had in the last few years. (First runner-up: Clinton St. Bakery's [NYC] ain't got nothing on this chop!!)

For dessert, the apple cobber with vanilla bean ice cream really, I mean REALLY hit the spot and ended the meal with a nice sweet finish. A warm, crispy, crusty, crunchy, mildly toasted bread crumb top, with a gooey apple-filled interior - paired with the cold refreshing taste of vanilla. Can't beat it. 

One appetizer, two mains and one dessert for under $90 incl tax+tip (without wine) - totally worth the money. I'll definitely come back the next time I'm in town.
author: Pam S.

description: Ok this food is seriously amazing. I had been here once before with family visiting from out of town but I think it was even better the last time. We sat outside along Hyde Street so that our pup could join. It was actually really fun to people watch from here. We tried the burrata toast, and the gnocchi for appetizers, and ordered a bottle of rose'. All super. For an entree I once again ordered the half chicken. I don't know what they do to the chicken but seriously it's the best chicken I have ever put in my mouth...and I eat chicken daily. The skin is cripy and the meat is perfectly moist. I wish I would of saved room for dessert but between half a chicken and the gourmet appetizers I was STUFFED. If you're looking for a fancy neighborhood restaurant with incredible food, and you haven't tried this place yet, just do it already. You won't regret it. Oh yeah I forgot to mention, the service was great. My hubby and I were really impressed how each staff members takes on different roles depending on the situation. If the food runner brings out your entrees, but notices you are out of water, then they will go refill your glasses. If the host/hostess steps out for a minute and notices you have dropped your fork, they'll go in and get you a new one. Great business practices and I am very impressed that the manager was able to instill that taking initiative attitude into all of his/her employees.
author: Kelsey K.

description: This is a favorite neighborhood Italian restaurant. It is way better than North Beach. The food is phenomenal and the atmosphere is very homey, quaint and very authentic.  The Burrata starter, fresh pappardelle with meat ragu and duck confit salad are outstanding.   They also allow you to order half portions, which is perfect for trying multiple dishes.
author: Laura S.

description: Loved this place! Took my boyfriend here for a surprise birthday dinner. The food was delicious, the ambiance was great, and the waiter was pleasant. AND the bread pudding was to die for! It's a must try!
author: Gina D.

description:
A special dinner to celebrate a special occasion. It was my sister's 30th birthday, and unlike our adventures to dive brunch spots in the 'loin (http://www.yelp.com/biz/munch-haven-san-francisco#hrid:B3P4yLnEaqlM4LykoNPHAw), this called for something a little more upscale. Long on our shared list (great minds think alike), Frascati it was.

You enter into a bustling and warm atmosphere, and the sound of cable cars rolling by adds to the ambiance. Service was prompt and knowledgeable, though the tone seemed a bit scripted.

Starters featured a very good fruit bruschetta (the peaches were divine), and a not as good watermelon salad (you are paying way too much for just a few slices of watermelon). For mains I was very impressed with sis' pork tenderloin, she offered a bite, I could have had five. Good but not as great was my half chicken. Too much skin, not enough artichoke and spinach complements. The chicken itself was great, but you are paying for the whole package.

Our close, a blackberry sorbet, was amazing.

Overall, not bad, though I've been more impressed elsewhere for less money. Frascati was missing that signature - in design, in food or in service - to warrant a fourth star.
author: Jason B.

description: The Roasted Half Chicken is amazing:  juicy inside and crisp outside.  I rarely order chicken when out at restaurants, but I definitely recommend it from Frascati.  The host/owner(?) and waitstaff were all top-notch.  Cute neighborhood off the Hyde-Powell cable car line.  Avoid the aggravation of trying to park around there.
author: Peter G.

description:
I ate about it!

This place is magical.  The chicken is delish. And if you are lucky enough to score a window seat, then you are lucky enough! Make a reservation. Cheers!
author: Kristina I.

description:
Had a wonderful belated Valentine's dinner here with the babes.  I had never heard of the place so I was a bit skeptical when his surprise led us to Frascati -- but i loved it. Good job bb!!

Decor, etc, is fairly nice but food is definitely what sets Frascati apart from the 1000's other great places in SF.

We ordered:
--Cheese Plate ($14) -- 3 types of cheeses, paired with an assortment of fresh and preserved fruits and nuts.  Great to snack on as you start on the wine.  Side note: Great wine selection here too.
--Grilled Flat Iron Steak ($27) -- So well marinated. Super garlicy -- a bit too salty, but meat is tender and cooked perfectly.  The polenta is gooey and creamy.  
-- Branzino (~$26) -- European seabss, seared 'til the filet has the perfect crispy crust. Fish very flavorful and tastes of the ocean -- which I'm usually not a fan of...I usually prefer a buttery Chilean bass, but boy, this was superb.  Bed of wild mushrooms made the perfect compliment.
--Chocolate Bread Pudding ($8) -- More molten chocolate cake than bread pudding -- but i have no complaints.  The homemade ice cream was the best!!

Upstairs seating looked like fun-- will definiely try to ask for it next time we make a reservation...and yes, there will be a next time :).
author: Kendra W.

description:
This place does a really good job as an upscale neighborhood restaurant, especially for the price.  It's not that cheap, but for the same quality you could definitely be paying more somewhere else.  Frascati has a lot of charm, especially with the cable-car passing by out front, and I found it very easy to feel comfortable.  The service was excellent as well.

As for the food, everything we had was really tasty although nothing on the menu is very adventurous or surprising.  I can attest, as others have, that the pork chop and bread pudding are excellent.  Also had a bit of the sardines appetizer, which was very nice.  Each of us cleaned our plates for all three courses.

You won't be wowed by any ultra-creative dishes at Frascati, but when you just want to go someplace that's low-key, has tons of charm, and has consistent quality Frascati is great.
author: Mike D.

description:
This place is amazing!  I've been here a couple of times & each time the food was awesome.  It's great for small groups and great for romantic date nights.  The service is excellent too.  The only downside is the neighborhood because it's a bit difficult to find parking, but that's not the restaurant's fault.

Here's what we had:
Ahi Tuna Tartare - really fresh, served with crostini
Pork Chop - huge portion, very tender & delicious
Sweet Corn Risotto -  amazing, I thought I died & went to heaven 
Vanilla Bean Panna Cotta - literally one of the best desserts we've had EVER!!
author: Kim D.

description:
We went to Frascati to celebrate Father's Day this year, thanks to Yelper's recommendations, and we were not disappointed!

We started with a couple appetizers, including the smoked salmon bruschetta, which was amazing. Definitely recommend ordering it if you're a fan of smoked salmon.  I'm sad to say I don't remember exactly what we all ordered for the main courses, but we all did really enjoy our meals.

The service was fantastic, as was the cozy atmosphere; it would definitely be good place to go for a date night, and Swensen's Ice Cream is practically right next door if you'd like some dessert... 

I do have to mention, though, what's with the mini bathroom?  It's like the size of a linen closet...
author: Kelley B.

description: One of my favorites in all of San Francisco.  Great for romantic dinners, or a business dinner.   The food is excellent and the staff are incredible.
author: Mark K.

description:
Love the low key Russian Hill location.
Love the very solid food. Especially the pork chop and duck confit salad.
Love the intimate, casually elegant, "SF" dining environment.

Why not 5 stars? I not exactly sure why. Maybe it was my particular seat (upstairs tucked up against the waiters' station) or the polite yet not particularly warm waiter (had dined at Kokarri the night before and the waiter was a-w-e-s-o-m-e). Something was missing for me.

I'd definitely go back - but not in a rush.
author: Deann M.

description:
I'm really not sure how this place has such a high rating. This place was only average, at the very best. Maybe the area is lacking for some Italian-style restaurants, but I wasn't impressed.

First of all, the food is expensive. Nothing really appealed to me on their menu, so I asked about having the gnocchi for an entree instead of an appetizer. They said they would go ahead and double the order for me. I got 20 undercooked gnocchi delivered to me in a mediocre, kinda flavorless sauce. Definitely not what I was expecting when most pasta dished are usually quite large and plentiful.

My husband's mushroom risotto was just OK. It was very creamy and way heavy. I don't know how you could finish a whole bowl of it.

The one good part was the artesianal cheese plate, which I would recommend. There were 4 different kinds of cheese with smaller items to complement the cheeses, such as figs and a sort of cranberry compote. It was tasty, but in my opinion, a bit overpriced for what you got.

We didn't have dessert, so I can't speak on that, but I had heard they were good. I also heard the restaurant was good too though, so take that for what it's worth.
author: Christina G.

description:
Definitely make a reservation since this place is very small. I called a day before and there were only 2 tables left for a party of 4 and the earliest was 8:15. It worked out perfectly for me though, and we were seated right away. Our waters were constantly refilled :) 

Appetizer + Main courses: 
1. Russet Potato Gnocchi (my 2nd favorite dish of the night) which had a delicious sauce with white truffle oil. We definitely dipped our bread in the sauce afterwards. 
2. Grilled Pork Chop with grilled peach and mango papaya salsa (my favorite of the night). The meat was perfectly cooked and was very juicy. 
3. Fresh Pappardelle with pulled pork (it was good, but the pasta stuck together)
4. Wild California Salmon (it was a little undercooked, but good flavor)
5. Maple Leaf Duck Breast (definitely way undercooked for someone like me who doesn't like red meat) The middle of each slice was basically raw meat. I couldn't take more than a bite from this dish. 

Desserts: 
1. Warm black and white chocolate bread pudding 
Probably the best bread pudding I've ever had. After a disaster making my own bread pudding, I have been afraid to try bread pudding again, or if I did, I didn't like it. This one was really good though! Hazelnut ice cream on top was delicious too.
2. Peach-Blueberry Cobbler
This wasn't bad either. I liked how much fruit there was inside.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Great stand by restaurant.

Even after the new owners took over from Rich Wood (Wood Tavern in Oakland) the food is top notch Italian.  Always inventive, always cooked to perfection. 

Definately make reservations because it is along the cable car route so the tourists flock.  If the weather is warm, definately eat outside on the two or three tables they set up on the few good weather SF days.
author: Neil M.

description:
We were in San Francisco for 1 night, and our close friends brought us here. They used to live in this neighborhood and said this was their go to place. We understand why!
The food: 
I had the gnocchi appetizer, which included peas, fava beans, asparagus, and a brown butter sauce finished with truffle oil.  So so delicious. The gnocchi was seared after it was cooked, giving it a wonderful taste and the combination of brown butter, favas, and asparagus was so nice.  Great texture and flavor. Others in our party had the burrata, stone fruit bruschetta, and balsamic fig bruschetta. All were very good (especially the burrata) but the gnocchi was the best. 
My entree was the roasted chicken, served with fingerling potatoes, artichokes, and baby onions. The chicken was cooked excellently, crisp skin and moist, tender meat. I felt it was slightly under seasoned. Others had the fresh tagliatelle (excellent fresh sauce and good bite with the sausage), pan seared bass (it was better than decent, but nothing super special), and grilled pork chop (tasty, but my friend remarked "it used to be much bigger"). Overall, the food was worth the $. 
Our waitress recommended the bread pudding, which sounded phenomenal, but we opted for swensons up the street (mistake, wish we stayed for the bread pudding.)
Service was spot on. Waitress was knowledgeable, friendly, and attentive without hovering. 

If you're in this part of town (or even if you're not), you should try Frascati. Well worthy!!
author: Michael H.

description:
I'm still dreaming about the dinner from Frascati's!

First off, the service is impeccable, simply amazing. 

Second, I couldn't imagine a more perfect restaurant to celebrate my birthday at, with one of my besties of all time, Courtney J.  We had the best seat in the house, by the window. Perfect people watching but we had our personal space as well in a busy restaurant. 

Third, the food was phenomenal!  We started with the gnocchi and roasted pear salad. Divine. Then we had the duck and the scallops. And to top it off, we had the bread pudding dessert. All too fabulous for words to describe.

This is going to be my favorite restaurant for a while.
author: Lisa L.

description:
This past Saturday, we had a very nice birthday dinner at Frascati.  It is located at the corner of Hyde/Green in the Russian Hill area.  There are several other restaurants in the area.  Parking is very difficult and we were lucky to find parking a couple of blocks away.  The cable car runs right by the restaurant.

We got there at 5:30 and had a nice table by the wall.  It is a small place serving Mediterranean style meals.  Apparently the menus change every week.  We started off with some salads -  a roasted pear salad with acorn squash, butter lettuce, goat cheese, spiced pecans and creamy tarragon vinaigrette ($10).  It was well presented and very tasty.  The dressing was flavorful without being overpowering.  The other salad was a duck confit salad with baby spinach, red onions, dried cherries, gorgonzola cheese and a light balsamic dressing ($11).  It was also very well presented, tasty, and not overpowering.  

French bread was provided along with a glassware of olive oil for dipping the bread.  The olive oil had a pleasant flavor and it might have been lemon. 

For our entree, we chose a side of spaghetti squash, seafood fettucine, and a seabass plate.  The prices of the entrees were in the mid $20s.  I can't remember what the items were officially called as I don't have a copy of their menu that week.  My fettucine had mussels, clams, shrimp, drenched in a creamy chopped basil sauce similar to a pesto sauce.  The only downside might be that it was too salty and may have been due to the mussels and clams.  Other than that it was delicious.

The seabass plate was a fillet that was browned and laying on a bed of assorted mushrooms.  The plate was very well presented and was scrumptous. The spaghetti squash looked liked spaghetti and it was my first time eating it.  I liked it. 

Afterwards they brought out a scoop of their homemade coconut sorbet with a little candle on it.  Like everything else in the place, the dessert was excellent.

For special occasions, this is a great place to go and we plan on coming back again.
author: Robert J.

description:
This is a lovely little restaurant that has great food!

We went here on a Sunday night and it was buzzing however we were luckily able to get a table and, in our opinion, the best table on the top mezzanine level.

There were four of us and we were all very happy with our meals, the service, the atmosphere and wine.

The total bill came to $180 so I do think this is a well priced meal.
author: Jodi W.

description: We had the best dinner at Frascati. The Ahi special was amazing...our Italian friends that were visiting wanted to go back for lunch every day they visited!  Some of the highlights were the Ahi, the Classic Roast Chicken, Duck confit, and the Gnocchi.  Best desserts in town: Cobbler, Bread Pudding and Hazelnut Ice Cream to die for! Great service, so warm and the owners are just wonderful.
author: Susan S.

description:
Went looking for a great place to eat in Russian Hill and was happy to find one just several blocks from my boyfriend's apartment! 

I was a little taken aback  (and turned off) by the overly fishy smell when walking in the door, but I got used to it and the food more than made up for it. 

I absolutely loved the wild mushroom bruschetta, and the roasted pear salad exceeded my expectations. Also enjoyed the russet potato gnocchi as an entree (a bit heavy for an appetizer unless you share) though to be fair I would probably love a piece of cardboard if it had truffle oil drizzled on top. Preferred my friend's entree - the prosciutto wrapped monkfish - and was pleasantly surprised to find the prosciutto wrapping very crispy, which is hard to do while also not overcooking the fish.

Overall a fun neighborhood spot!
author: Amy F.

description:
I'm saddened that they've managed to lose a star in my book.  I absolutely love the food here and there is usually little to critique.  This is the reason why my SO and I return time after time (four, so far).  Here's where they lost me on our last visit (last night):

- made reservations with a special request to be seated by the window.  I've made this request on a separate occasion as well.  It feels that both times, they've failed to acknowledge my request.  Each time we walk in, they have a table ready for us somewhere in the middle of the restaurant.  It's not until I mention that it was noted on the reservation that a table by the window is preferred, that they give us other options.  On neither occasion did they apologize or even acknowledge that they were not able to fill our request.  It was like this request was lost and the host had not even seen this noted on the reservation.

- the ambiance has drastically changed.  There used to be a romantic feel to this place.  It was dimly lit and gave off the mood of dinner by candlelight.  This is no longer the case.  It has lost it's flare with its lighting and is sterile in comparison.

- now to the closet sized bathroom that I mentioned in my last review.  I had said that it was small with little wiggle room.  You figure with a space that tiny the bathroom will be immaculate.  This was not the case, at least not when I went in.  Maybe it was because my visit was at the end of the night when everything was winding down.  But this should be no excuse.

But I must say, in other cases, all these offenses would be stacked against the restaurant.  In this case, I give them a little leeway since their food is a dream.  I am absolutely in love with the maple leaf duck.  The waitress we had last night was amazing.  She had a number of wine suggestions to go with our meal.  The one we went with was perfect.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Delicious!!! A must go, especially for special occasions :)

Hyde street is such a charming place to be... you've got the cable car, tree lined streets, and views of nob hill. It's such a beautiful place to be in San Francisco. 

The restaurant is very cute but also looks like it can be very romantic. There is a second level with seating which adds a nice touch. Went here on one of the hottest days of the year and the restaurant does not have air conditioning... so they set up tables outside along the side walk. This was amusing because we noticed a slight tilt in our food and drinks.

I liked how they serve their bread with olive oil -- I LOVE dipping bread in olive oil, mmmmmm. We ordered the watermelon salad (which sounded yummy on the menu - especially for a hot day but the "salad" turned out to be four pieces of watermelon, srsly? But the Duck Confit Salad was delicious!!! I do not like to eat salads made with spinach but I could not get enough of this one... and the duck was delectable (my mouth is watering just thinking about it!)

On to dessert! We had the Pavlova (not impressed) and the Warm Black and White Chocolate Bread Pudding with hazelnut ice cream (OMG nom nom nom!). Throw in two glasses of really good wine and our bill was pretty expensive already :O 

Overall, this place is DELICIOUS and I can not wait to eat such yummy food again!! ...the next visit will get a 5 star rating, I just know it
author: Jennie S.

description:
*yawn*

I thought I'd be the rebel in this line of exquisite and excellent reviews only because I have not been back since we broke up.

My ex and I use to ride over on his motorcycle to this little quaint sliver in the wall of buildings lining Hyde.  And even though most of the time, we missed dinner, I would lose myself in their absolute decadent and sinister desserts.

The Warm Black and White Chocolate Bread Pudding is f-a-b-u-l-o-u-s-ly creamy, warm, thick textured, and just melts all over your tongue.  The hazlenut ice cream adds a nutty rustic feature to this dish.  Try kissing right thereafter.  

In the future, I'll come back.  But not on a bike.  For the positivity currently flowing due to a wonderful meal of sushi, I'll up the stars to a "4".
author: Miika M.

description:
Yumilicious.  Good food, great waitstaff, relaxed environment - what is there not to like?  I had the cheese plate to start and the ahi tuna as my main course.  Both were amazing.  The "four cheese" cheese plate was a dairy lover's delight.  For my main course, I had the seared ahi tuna with greens, potatoes and...I think that was bacon.  Some sort of deliciously crispy pork product was mixed in with my greens.  As a finishing touch, we had the profiteroles with creme anglaise.  Yum...

And I always love a great waiter/waitress.  My friend and I had no idea what we wanted to order, and the waitress offerred to help us pick something on our price range.  She found a great wine at an affordable price...

The neighborhood is great, and it's a fabulous place to bring friends from out of town...
author: Wendy L.

description: Had a great dinner here with my Dad.  We tried the chicken and sea bass entrees, both were amazing.  My dad told about 5 different Frascati employees how much he enjoyed his meal, the man speaks the truth :)
author: Brianna M.

description: This place is a small gem on Hyde st.  The steak tartar and the russet potato gnocchi are amazing.  I actually when 2 nights back to back for the same dishes.  If you are in Russian Hill and are looking for one of the best places to eat, this is it.
author: Iskra M.

description:
Very good dinner here recently. We started with the bruchetta, which was a bit unusual, but it was still tasty. 

Then, we shared the watermelon salad (quite good), the fish dish (the bed of sauce it was sitting on was amazing), gnocchi (wow!!), and the risotto (heaven!!). 

I look forward to coming back!
author: Art A.

description:
Please don't go. It makes it harder to me to get a spot in my favorite SF restaurant.

Everything is top notch.

Don't miss the desserts. The chocolate bread pudding is amazing, so is the panacotta.
author: Yann K.

description:
Took a friend out to dinner for his birthday and we both thought it was amazing!

Gnocchi and burrata/heirloom tomato apps were both super delicious in their own ways. You can taste the freshness of the ingredients with each bite...mmm..

Friend had fresh pappardelle pasta and said it was fresh and tasty. I had the roasted chicken and it had great flavor.

We had the black and white bread pudding and coffee to finish the evening. We both thought the bread pudding was good with the hazelnut ice cream but it was rich. 

The timing of the courses were flawless! Very intimate experience...almost too intimate but the food makes up for it!

Bathroom is super tiny, my closet is bigger than this bathroom.

Reservations are a must for this place and I can see how parking is a pain in the ass! I was lucky enough to find a spot near lombard and walk down to the restaurant. On my way, there was a lot that offered $10 parking for 2 hours...

I can't wait to come again!
author: Wendy L.

description:
5 Stars for Food & Service!

Truly exceptional food and an even more impressive service staff. We sat upstairs on the cool little balcony and although we were isolated they stayed on top of everything we needed. (side note balcony is above the kitchen so if youre bothered by really good smells and maybe a little smoke you shouldnt sit there).

Duck - tender, not too gamey, perfectly cooked with a tasty sauce

Brick Chicken - Juicy and flavorful, if i could eat handfuls of the crispy skin all day I would.

Tagliatelle - pasta was fresh and ragu sauce flavorful and tender

Bread Pudding - um, yeah, you should get this.

We will definitely be back to this incredible spot.
author: Jordan W.

description:
To surmise, Frascati is simply an excellent establishment and offers a top notch dinning experience. I had never been there before, yet I chose it for a special family outing and none of us were disappointed. On the contrary, we all had fantastic meals. My mom, dad, sister and I all ordered different starters, and all were delicious. I veered away from having a salad (as I already have one every day) and instead chose a comforting and flavorful tomato, eggplant soup, something which I thought was very much elevated by the subtle presence of the latter ingredient. I enjoyed it very much, yet my sister was totally enamored by the prosciutto and figs with bleu cheese; she said the preparation of the figs and the balsamic syrup-glaze that came with them was perfect,  and to me it looked as though she had never tasted anything better. 
For my entrée I had the pork chop, and I could not have been more satisfied with the dish. Occasionally pork chops can be finicky and at times it is difficult to cook them until they are just right, yet here it has been perfected. It was tender, moist, flavorful, and I have never tasted one which was better prepared. It came with a wonderfully complex compote on top and more sauce below, and it was simply fantastic. Polenta was served with is as well, and it too was delicious, but it's true purpose was to enhance the meat, a job it did excellently. It was the kind of dish which makes going to restaurants such fun; it's something that you just can't really have at home even if you are a very experienced cook (I asked the chef what the secret was to the pork chop, and he explained that brining it a day in advance does the trick. That is something I will definitely be trying).
To finish the meal I had a white and dark chocolate breading pudding with walnuts, caramel sauce, and hazel nut ice cream. It was out of this world. In addition, there is plenty to share, and it might even be a bit much for two people (even in my family of four I ended up eating almost two thirds of it. It was soooo good though).
However, what is so important to me in determining the quality of a restaurant is not only the food, but the overall atmosphere. To me, an excellent environment is an ingredient which can't go un added in a truly great dinning out experience. In the case of Frascati, I'm glad to say it's a very pleasant place to be in. It has a great tucked away location and just getting there is very nice. The restaurant itself is a very intimate space with low, yet warm lighting and an open kitchen which is very much a part of the dinning area. The close tables combined with all the people create and  but pleasing din, and the multiple rooms and layers make for a cozy feel. The very small but well decorated restroom is accessed by going down a peculiar set of stairs beside the kitchen, and although it sounds strange using the facilities is a pleasant experience. The close quarters, bustling people, and charming décor really makes a person feel as though they are part of the restaurant when inside, and that is a feeling I truly enjoyed.
Frascati is well serviced and the pricing is truly very reasonable for such high quality food; I don't remember seeing an entrée over thirty dollars. Although there is no bar, if you're looking for a great dinner to remember, I highly recommend you try it here. A warning, though, parking is a nightmare (try taking the cable car) and a reservation is a very good idea.
author: Will H.

description: Light crowd on a Tuesday night, easy to get a reservation, nice atmosphere, we sat on the second level so we could watch the cooks.  I had duck, my wife had a paparadella sugo, they were excellent.  The desert portions are huge, we ordered two because we were feeling gluttonous, it was too much.  All in all good price, SF quality, nice location.
author: Theodore G.

description:
I loved Frascati. My boyfriend and I went for Valentine's Day and had the best time. 

The waitress was very nice and very knowledgable. She recommended excellent wine for us and was very attentive. 

The food was very good as well: we had the cheese plate and mushroom bruschetta, I had the chopped pear salad, and boyfriend had something with seafood that he loved (aghh memory fail on the name of it) AND THE DESSEEERRRTTTT was so indulgent and phenomenal. Chocolate Bread Pudding....ohhhhh man

The restaurant/environment was LOVELY and just adorable. We were put in the corner in the back room, so we didn't get to fully enjoy it like the people on the little balcony did.  But we were also 30 minutes late because we could NOT find parking...do not drive here it took us 45 minutes to find a place to park. 

Very good restaurant. Definitely try it
author: Ashley B.

description: This was a really good place to eat. The filet Mignon was so tender and flavorful. The crab risotto had the perfect texture and every bite had just enough fresh crab. Then there was the scallops. I've had scallops but these were perfection.  This is what heavens meat would taste like. For dessert i recommend going some where else. Its not that it was not good but you can have this anywhere and probably better. The actual place is really small so definitely make a reservation. We went for a special birthday but Its got a romantic feel and lighting to match. I would love to go back but I feel I had my experience of Frascati and sometimes that's enough and with so many wonderful restaurants in SF ..on to the next.
author: shirley c.

description:
Bread pudding-- 8.5 of 10
Pannacotta--------8 of 10 ( limon's pannacotta is better though)
Ahi tuna-----------8 of 10
Duck---------------9 of 10
author: Ana M.

description:
I may have to try you one more time before really making up my mind ... but until then you teeter between 3 and 4 stars.  

Your dishes were good, but it seemed there there was A LOT going on within each dish.  My lamb loin special was tasty ... but I thought the flavors were a little overwhelming.  The pork chop was flavored perfectly and it was oh so juicy!  I'm just not sure the eggplant puree and red onion marmalade were necessary.  Even the gnocchi, which I loved, was much busier than other gnocchi dishes I've had.  

Despite these minor complaints, I'll be back again.  The restaurant itself is very cute and homey.  And I have absolutely no complains about the gnocchi and bread pudding ... scrumdiddlyumptious!
author: Dina H.

description: Fantastic food, great ambience.  Also, and perhaps most importantly, Justin was absolutely a life-saver on multiple fronts (getting us the perfect table, updating our reservation time, etc.).  Can't wait to come back.
author: Mihir G.

description: This is a really nice, classy place with a tiny bathroom.  The food was outstanding.  I came here with my family for my graduation dinner and we were all blown away.  We expected it to be italian and found it to be more italian-american.  Still, we were satisfied with everything we ate.  The zinfindel was a bit different from what I was expecting, but c'est la vie.
author: Mike V.

description: This restaurant is a gem. My husband and I took a cable car one evening and noticed Frascati was buzzing inside as we drove past it. We looked it up on Yelp and saw so many great reviews we decided to try it. This is one of those places where everything was perfect.  The service was great. Our server suggested wines to accompany or food.  He suggested we have half glasses of three different wines.  The wines were perfect.  We ordered a delicious chicken dish and mushroom risotto .  The server also suggested we try the Panna Cotta which was amazing. The ambiance was glowing and romantic. Needless to say I loved this place..
author: S And B D.

description:
The reviews for Frascati are super, and so my husband and I came to dine with high expectations. We were not disappointed! The food was excellent, and the ambiance was warm and unpretentious. The service was very quick and attentive. 
We had:
- Steak tartare - delicious, well seasoned. 
- Duck confit salad - highly recommend! One of the best bites of the night: sweet and tart dried cherries with perfectly crispy duck.
- Filet mignon - meat was perfectly cooked, the side (root veg hash) was nothing sensational.
- Roasted half chicken - highly recommend! This was totally the dark horse of the meal. I don't usually order chicken when I'm out (doesn't seem fancy enough?), but I'm so glad I did. This was the best chicken I've ever had. Super juicy, super crispy, with a nice bright sauce/jus. People of yelp, other things on the menu may sound more exotic and difficult to prepare, but get this chicken. It is so good. 
- Black and white chocolate bread pudding with hazelnut ice cream - the ice cream was good, nice chunks of hazelnut; the bread pudding was not too sweet.
author: jane c.

description:
What a perfect date night. This is a beautiful restaurant with a wonderful wine selection and a delicious menu. 

The russet potato gnocchi starter is the best gnocchi I have had, clearly made with the best of ingredients in house. Following with just as high of praise their main courses left me thinking about when I will go back.

Our server was very attentive and guided us through the menu very well, I would follow his recommendations.
author: Barbara C.

description:
Chose this spot based on other Yelp reviews for a nice dinner with my wife on our visit to the Bay area. It did not disappoint. 

We snagged the last reservation they had for a Friday night (9:30pm). After a short trip on a cable car from our hotel we arrived a few minutes early and were received with a warm welcome and quickly escorted to a slightly small but cozy table upstairs overlooking the kitchen. The view allowed us to observe the wonderful food being prepared beneath and delight in the aromas wafting up.

We shared the Gnocchi for starters, and it was wonderful. For our mains my wife had the pan seared Filet Mignon and I had the Duck Breast. They were  a treat. Great presentation, wonderful textures and flavors from the accompanying sides and incredible flavors.

Dessert was no let down either: The Chocolate Bread Pudding....just WOW! We shared it and we couldn't finish it, but I really wanted to. It was incredible.

Our server was very friendly and knowledgable, the ambience was great and we were both very satisfied with the whole experience. The bill was $118 (incl. tax) for an app, two mains, a dessert and three glasses of wine. I thought that was reasonable for the quality of the food and wine, and would have no trouble going back and paying that again!
author: Craig B.

description:
I am a fan of neighborhood restaurants in SF and here is another one I can recommend.  Appetizers, main courses and the irresistible bread  pudding were outstanding.

Then there is the service: our waiter was an 11 on a scale of 10, Don't miss this place.
author: Paul B.

description:
Where to even begin?!  My boyfriend and I absolutely LOVE this restaurant!  We went there for his birthday last year, and again this year.  Everything about the restaurant is incredible...the ambiance, the service, the FOOD, you name it.

We were seated at a very nice table upstairs, candlelit, very romantic atmosphere.  Greeted nicely by the host who led us upstairs.  Our waitress Angela was amazing!!!  She really made our night that much better - great personality, advice, and just genuine warmth and friendliness.   Angela, you ROCK.

APPS:  We started with the grilled pear salad....little gems (of grilled pear), grilled acorn squash, dried cranberries, goat cheese, spiced pecans, all drizzled in a mouthwatering tarragon vinaigrette.  We loved it so much we ordered another after we pretty much licked our first plate clean in a matter of 2 minutes.
