I would suggest the chicken. My only complaint, is that it had too many unbaked breadcrumbs that made the dish very salty.  Still, it was good.

All in all. I won't be returning. I am glad I tried it. I don't think it was worth what we paid though.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Poor Frascati, or maybe poor me.  I had to take away a star after coming here the 2nd time this past Saturday.  It wasn't as good as the first time.....

Our server was just odd.  He wasn't mean or rude, but just had a bunch of oddities.  He kept giving my guy the check and the wine list and I wondered if it was a subconscious "you're the white dude, with all Koreans, you must be the responsible one".  When he brought out the dessert he giggled it before he set it down.  Why?

Anyway, with that said, the food wasn't as spectacular as I remembered.  The gnocci was pretty good and I believe the duck was as good as before, but the rest of the dishes also had oddities about them.  The pork was cooked well, but my man felt it was too sweet.  My girlfriend's risotto was off the hook, until I tasted some sand, which most likely came from unwashed mushrooms,which makes sense because you're not supposed to run them under water, but crunching on sand is an awful experience.  Then the risotto had a weird floral after-taste that didn't taste bad but tripped me the heck out.  Finally my fish dish was cooked okay but very bland.  (NOPA's halibut still rocks the roof.)

The restaurant still gets 4 stars for their desserts.  The pana cotta was still divine regardless from its giggly intro, and the chocolate ice cream was smoothly delicious.

Honestly, I know I wanted to be a regular there, but I've changed my mind.  But I know I'll be going back for the pana cotta.
author: Susan C.

description: Cute little spot! The ambiance is warm and inviting and the service was very good, but the food wasn't very memorable.  Most of our meal was perfectly fine, but the fish we ordered was overcooked.. Not too much of a damper since all the flavors were solid, but I expected a little more, especially for the price.  I'm not sure I'd go back given the plethora of other choices in SF, but definitely worth a shot.
author: Jen K.

description: Charming neighborhood gem with delicious food and good service.  Back  in the day I went on a lot of first dates here and it hasn't lost any of it's charm.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Last night, my beau and I decided to celebrate my birthday by going to dinner at Frascati.  He's relatively new to the area, so I gave him an authentic SF experience by leading him on a death march up Mason St. from Union Square, then over Russian Hill to this little restaurant on the corner of Green and Hyde.  

He was not amused by the march, but his mood improved when the wine arrived.  We shared a salad and appetizer - mixed green salad, and mushroom gnocchi.  

The gnocchi were a revelation, light and fluffy in a rich and complex mushroom sauce.  The salad had some interesting peppery greens in it, and the dressing was good, but I felt a restaurant of this caliber could have done something more original than adding dried cranberries, apples, and goat cheese.  May I suggest trying figs, pistachios, and gorgonzola?

The entrees arrived, with more wine.  I had the scallops, and he had the chicken.  By this time, all his annoyance over the surprise aerobic work-out had disappeared, as he groaned with pleasure at every bite of chicken.  The chicken had a beautiful sauce, potatoes, and young artichokes.  My scallops were equally delicious, seared on the outside and tender inside, accompanied by carrot puree and shredded cabbage.

Regarding desert, I would have to agree with other Yelp reviewers - our apple cobbler was huge  - too big even for two people, and much too sweet.  Let's go for something a bit more sophisticated next time.  

The service was friendly, efficient, and unpretentious.  The nice waitress came running after us with a forgotten bag as we walked out towards the street.  The setting is just like that Sinatra song, with little cable cars climbing halfway to the stars.  In all, it was a very nice evening.
author: Dina C.

description: Another terrific SF meal.  We started with Monterey Bay Sardines with Meyer Lemon Aioli and Russet Potato Gnocchi with an earthy medley of mushrooms, peas & fava beans in truffle oil.  The main courses were wonderful  Renta, a warm & very accommodating server, perfectly complemented the meal.  Can't wait to come back!
author: Chris O.

description: Thank you again Yelp! While traveling my husband and I wanted to get a five star meal without any of the added expense and commercialism of touristy San Francisco. We found it here in this intimate bistro. Food was superb and service great. While the duck, as others have mentioned, was wonderful, the best thing I ate was the mushroom bruschetta appetizer. A great find!
author: Emily H.

description:
Had a very nice time at this restaurant, we didn't feel that it really lived up to it's hype. The 3 of us started with salads and a potato-leek soup, had a salmon dish, roast chicken and a pork chop for entrees, and an apple cobbler, chocolate bread pudding and affogato for dessert. Portions were good (desserts were definitely for two people each). The pork chop was undercooked and the other dishes were unremarkable. Service was pleasant and unpretentious, but nothing special.
There were some (more than 3) strange bugs at our table and one landed in someone's drink, but otherwise the restaurant seemed perfectly tidy.
No valet is a bit annoying for that neighborhood.
author: Michael B.

description: Food was outstanding,wine selection was excellent, staff was warm and friendly.  Reasonably priced, too, which is a big surprise.
author: Greg B.

description:
I quite literally never feel comfortable giving five stars. With so many things that can go wrong in the course of an evening at any given moment, in this business. It is quite impossible. Nevertheless. I have dined at Frascati at least 20 times in the course of the last year. And I have never once had a bad meal; nor bad service; nor bad atmosphere. This place is, hands down, my favorite San Francisco dining spot. And I know of what I speak. I spent 3 years reviewing restaurants for radio, television and print. It is all at once upscale and your neighborhood joint. 

It is always packed, so make reservations. Once I wanted a space at the bar and they were so busy, they gave me a glass of bubbles while I waited on someones stairs. I brought my chef boyfriend in from Sweden and he didn't stop talking about the place for two weeks. They invite me in with jeans, and make me feel like a queen when I am dressed up. The servers make you feel like family, and so does Jon, the owner. 

You must have the gnocchi starter, and any one of their seasonal soups. I love the grilled bread salad, and duck breast entree. I have never had a bad dish here, nor a bad experience. 

Do yourself a favor and go here. It is a place for romance, groups, tourists, a first date or a night reading a book at the bar. 

Go here. You will certainly go back.
author: Gina H.

description:
Saffron Cioppino, 
Washed down with Champagne, 
Unforgettable.
author: Brian J.

description: I chose this place for dinner in May 2011 based on highly rated Yelp reviews and it's location for dinner with some out of town guests.  We arrived about 7 minutes late for our Saturday evening reservation to find that our table had been given away and asked to wait "about 15 minutes" to see what they could do for us.  So we stepped outside and waited...had some wine...a little more wine...and about 90 minutes later we had a table for 6 ready. To be fair the host kept checking in with us to ensure we were "ok" during our lengthy wait. Long story short, food was great, service good, and a very charming little restaurant.  This is a small neighborhood place without a lot of tables so be sure to arrive on time for your reservation or be prepared to wait...and I'm glad we waited for the next table as the food was well worth it.
author: Kent W.

description:
Strong start, weak finish. My husband and I went to Frascati for his birthday. We are parents of young children and on a single income, thus now rarely eat out, particularly at nice restaurants. So, he found Frascati on Yelp and we decided to give it a go.

They were extremely welcoming, even on the phone, when we first thought we'd have our 7-week-old in tow (in a car seat) and explained we'd need a larger table or a place to tuck our son. We arrived and the host was lovely; super friendly. Our [first] server was really sweet and knowledgeable: explained several wines and was honest about what was extraordinary on the menu (and what was not). 

The wine was awesome; ditto our starters (including the duck confit salad). My husband's flat iron steak was terrific, and the outside of my halibut was wonderful. But my fish was raw on the inside. I thought, oh, did I forget this was pan-seared? It was too late to send it back, particularly because our server left us with another server (what a terrible practice), who never came over to our table, except to drop the check before I asked for it and to check on it while we were finishing our wine (tacky). Our desserts were fabulous - cheesecake and chocolate bread pudding.

Overall, not an awesome experience. Food was mostly wonderful, but the service was inconsistent and overall poor. Such a bummer after dropping $200 on a meal and $75 for a babysitter.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Sooo good! 

Here's what to get: The Duck; The Pork Chop; and the Warm Chocolate Bread Pudding with Homemade Hazelnut Ice Cream... yum. You will not be disappointed :D 

THANKS, Frascati!!
author: Brian B.

description: Service was wonderful!  I ordered the duck, it was okay.  I also ordered the chocolate bread pudding and it was wonderful!  My friend ordered the chicken, and it was delicious!!  Her sherbet was also.  Would definitely come here again.
author: Megan W.

description: Absolutely amazing chicken! I actually didn't believe that chicken could be that good. I really really enjoyed it and I am getting hungry just thinking about it. Great atmosphere, friendly staff, and gorgeous location too.
author: Chris S.

description:
I had been looking forward to going to Frascati for 2 weeks and it did not disappoint! My parents were in town from the east coast so I took them here last Friday night.

I had made reservations on Open table and we were seated promptly 
at 8:30. One of the coolest things about the places is that the kitchen is open to the restaurant. We were seated on the upper level with a view right down into the kitchen. So we were able to watch some of the food being prepared - a cool ambiance. Our server was also very helpful and friendly.

For starters we had the cheese plate and French wine. They are always rotating cheese here, but the Maytag blue was the favorite. 

We also had the gnocchi with truffle oil and a lettuce wedge salad with pumpkin seeds. Gnocchi is one of my favorite things and combined with truffle oil it was heavenly.  For dinner 3 of us had the leg of lamb and one had the bass. The lamb was succulent and cooked to perfection (medium rare) with very interesting sauces.  SO GOOD. 

Overall, great service, the food was all fresh, served in good portions and perfectly flavored.

We were too full come dessert but oh I can't wait for the next excuse to go back!!
author: Katie W.

description:
Gnocchi, cooked to perfection.
Asparagus salad, perfectly seasoned.
Pan seared arctic char, tender and delicious
Vanilla bean panna cotta - sweet and light tasting.
Ambiance, perfect!
author: Pug P.

description:
One of the things that really bothers me is when the wait staff leans over your table waiting for you to drop your fork so they can pickup your plate! That's what I felt like they did here. The food was pretty good, but a bit expensive in my opinion (even though I didn't pay), but I guess it's due to the area of the city and ambiance! 

Overall, I thought it was ok and I might go back, but it wouldn't be the first on my list.
author: A M.

description: Hidden away in the Russian Hill area, amazing I have not been here before since it has been here since 1987.  Cute storefront setting and yes there was an active kitchen which is nice to know before you go.  It is a nice get away from Downtown and the food was unique and what I like about this place was the staff worked as a team to make things happen.  From the owner placing the butcher paper on the table to the   Sommelier clearing tables.  Of course I had to try the octopus salad and the chorizo gave it a good bite and my Duck breast was a work of art.  That duck was cooked medium rare to perfection and the serving was one of the largest I have had.  The ravioli had a spiciness to it but not overpowering.  Hats off to Chef Pawlk for having the right hints of flavor and spices to make me come back.  BTW - if you are worried about getting a cab back to your hotel i saw cabs come by every 5 minutes to see if anyone was needing a ride back to downtown.
author: Toby N.

description: Excellent venue to have dinner with friends, staff very attentive, menu well thoughtout. Wine list excellent for the size of the menu.
author: Amado R.

description: One of the best meals I have had in a long time. Their pork chop was amazing. Moist tender and flavorful
author: Jim O.

description:
I have such fond memories of this place! I've dined at Fracscati on three separate occasions - a birthday, semi-reunion and group outing - and had an amazing meal each time. The restaurant is very "homey" and cozy so I would recommend coming here with a plus one or small group to avoid waiting forever. 

Favorite appetizers: Watermelon salad (seasonal) and homemade gnocchi 

Entree: Maple leaf duck breast. I am not a fan of spatzel and replace it with potatoes or another side 

Dessert: Apple Crumble with ice cream.. baked to perfection!
author: Lan H.

description: Went here for my birthday last year.  Loved it!  So cute and charming.  I had always wanted to have dinner there and was reminded that each time I went by it.  Finally, my best friend took me there for dinner on my birthday!  Loved it!  The food, service, decor, everything was perfect.  Great wine list too!
author: Chloe M.

description:
I am a relatively new yelper. Nonetheless, from what I have read (and very much appreciated by other Y'ers), I have, with friends, benefited from the various scenarios. 

I was in SF last week and happ'd upon the various reviews of FRASCATI.  There was immediate intrigue. Besides being cable-car friendly, upon arrival (and with a prior reservation), FRASCATI exceeded every expectation. 

Pardon me for not remembering our food and wine selections  -  we were most graciously greeted and seated. Service on the evening that we dined was great. We were well taken care of; as, I trust, others. 

The faire is intriguing. The duck egg appetizer and the chicken entre were miraculous. I guess I/we were mezmerized.....and just enjoyed everything, including the cable car back to our hotel.

I will return.......this spot is not just a local's hangout and can/should be appreciated by others from anywhere in SF or just if visiting from outside the area.

FIVE STARS
author: Steve L.

description:
my boyfriend and i went here to celebrate our anniversary and frascati did not disappoint (although we had to walk all the way from union square...we clearly know nothing about distance perception). we had reservations but ended up arriving earlier and they gladly seated us with no problems. the service was excellent and not overbearing. we didn't really have to wait long for anything until the end, when the restaurant got a little busier. 

i had the risotto and he had the pork chop and they were both amazing! it was one of those things where i literally stuffed myself to eat it all because i didn't want it to go to waste. we ended the dinner with the chocolate bread pudding, per yelpers' recommendations, and it was incredible. it had the crispy edges you find on the end brownie pieces and had just right amount of sweetness/chocolate. my boyfriend fell in love with the homemade ice cream that it came with. all in all, a huge success!
author: Catherine J.

description: Coming from Denver, this place is the neighborhood restaurant of our dreams. We have eaten here 3 times in the last year. At night the glowing lights on the corner of Hyde and Green suggest a warm and romantic dinner spot -- come on in  -- it is terrific. Make a reservation in advance. The service, the wine list, the ambience, the food will all delight you. Borders on 5 stars, but maybe one-half short overall (a little cramped/noisy)? Given our pleasant experiences and the thrill of riding the cable car from the front door of the restaurant back to our hotel near Union Square, I am throwing all reservations to the wind. Ok -- 5 stars!
author: Michael H.

description:
If you look up "great little neighborhood restaurant" in the dictionary, there should be a picture of Frascati there. From the location (tucked in a corner of Russian Hill, close proximity to equally cute neighborhood wine bar Bacchus), to the vibe (classy without being pretentious) to the service (extremely friendly and laid back) this place has it all. And the food rocks! 

We ordered a few starters and an entree which was the perfect amount of food for one hungry guy and one girl who ate half a marzipan scone she forgot she had in the car while driving over to Russian Hill an hour and half before, and was therefore in the mood for something light. We shared the grilled asparagus with a poached duck egg, the grilled Monterey Bay sardines, and the grilled bread salad. We also got the bluenose bass (pan roasted, I know you thought I was going to say grilled again, didn't you?) with vegetables. The food was satisfying and hearty without being overly rich or heavy, perfect for a meal on the late side, or if you make a bad judgment call when timing your snacks.

The wine list has a lot of variety, prices are about average for the city but pours are very generous. Nothing gets me misty eyed like a generous wine pour, let me tell you.

I plan to return to Frascati soon, and often.
author: Angie R.

description:
3 and half stars
Its been three or four years since I have been back   - but something definitely has changed..

*Pork chop that I ordered was served to me raw - which is really no excuse 
*My wife ordered the bass - which was really ordinary - she didnt seem excited about it.
*is it me or did they increase the portions of that delicious bread pudding? felt like i was at the cheesecake factory or at applebees.

SAD  -- did they change chefs?
author: Christian S.

description: My boyfriend and I were meeting a friend that lives in the city, on a whim I picked this place.  What a find! The atmosphere was great, the food was amazing, and the wine list is great! We ordered a few appetizers, wine, dinner, dessert, and coffee.  We are looking forward to coming here again.
author: Leslie T.

description:
This bustling little Russian Hill restaurant is like a twinkle in the sky: it rests on a fairly quiet residential block of Hyde near a few other restaurants, and is usually the busiest and most packed spot each night. Once you've dined here, you understand why. 

At Frascati, there's attentive, welcoming service; a knowledgeable wait staff that offers thorough descriptions and recommendations about dishes and wines; and a tight but intimate dining area that has the feel of a small, hidden neighborhood gem as well as the fine food and overall experience of a well-established restaurant competing with the best this city has to offer.

Starters I've tried include the duck confit salad, mushroom bruschetta, and tuna tartare -- all worth trying (especially the salad). I ordered the risotto, which was very tasty; had a slab of the venison, which wasn't at all gamey (it wasn't what I expected, but was still juicy in all of its medium rare glory); as well as the pork chop, which was also decent. I tried two side plates: the spaghetti squash and the brussel sprouts, both of which were quite rich (and buttery).

For dessert, we had the warm chocolate bread pudding, topped with ice cream, as well as the crispy apple cobbler, also served with ice cream.

For our party of three, the bill came out to about $250 with tip (that included a low to moderately priced syrah). Unless you have the funds to splurge frequently, dining here is reserved for special occasions.
author: Cheri R.

description:
My gals and I went to Frascati for dinner to kick off the bachelorette party. We had an early reservation at 5:30 on a Sunday evening and the restuarant was pretty empty but the crowd started trickling in around 6 pm. 

Food: In one word - Yummy! We had the gnochhi and heirloom tomato salad for first course. The gnocchi was divine but almost everything with a generous serving of truffle oil. The heirloom tomato salad was OK at best - about 3 slices of tomato with some feta cheese for ~$10 so not the best value. For the main course, we ordered the risotto (4.5 stars), bass (3.5 stars), pork chop (4 stars), chicken (4 stars) and scallops (3.5 stars). Dessert was great - especially the chocolate bread pudding and the mango ice-cream. 

Service - was attentive without being intrusive. Adam was fun and friendly and made good recommendations. 

Drawback - Corkage. We were charged $20 for the first bottle we bought and $25 for the second bottle. I personally think that $20 is a bit high for a neighborhood restauarnt but I thought the second fee of $25 was aggregious, especially since we didn't we get new glasses. So we basically spent $25 for some one to pop a cork and pour wine into our glasses which we could have happily done ourselves. I know restaurants have a high margin on wine bottles but to try and make the up the margin in corkage is unfair and takes away from the experience. 

All in all: I would definitely go back for the food but may just order a glass of wine instead of picking from their menu or bringing my own.
author: Rumesha A.

description:
I keep Frascati menus by my pillow so when I can't sleep at night I  read over the menu and dream happy dreams of what my next great Frascati meal will be.  

I somehow didn't go to Frascati for over 6 months, and then went back twice in the past week.  The FRESH FETTUCCINI went off the menu for the winter, but it's back and better than ever!  It was already my favorite dish to begin with.  They've added some chili flakes to give it a little kick, and if I remember last year's ingredients correctly, the baby scallops were replaced by Manila clams and mushrooms.  Also, the spinach anchovy pesto has now become anchovy pesto.  At first, I was skeptical seeing the changes on the menu, but I was wowed upon the first bite.

New Reviews:
GRILLED ASPARAGUS - These are very lightly grilled, in fact it was still so juicy that it tasted steamed.  The poached duck egg is a nice touch.  It's not my favorite appetizer but I'd order it again.
WATERMELON SALAD - I have no idea how they came up with this, but it is genius!
FRESH FETTUCCINI - Need I say more?  It's my favorite dish!
SAUTEED BLACK BASS "LIVORNESE" - I only got a few bites of my boyfriend's fish but this is a fabulous dish.  I'm not a big fish fan, but it is worth getting here.
PAN SEARED FILET MIGNON - We've ordered this a few times, and it is consistently medium-rare, just the way we want it!  Very lean, yet juicy.
ROASTED HALF CHICKEN - I am not a big fan of chicken, and I especially don't like chicken breast.  I rarely order chicken anywhere, but this is Frascati, the place that gets me to like things that I don't like, if that makes sense.  I ordered the half chicken last week and it's excellent -- slightly crispy flavorful skin with moist chicken (mostly boneless breast).
author: Darlene W.

description: We came here for an early-Valentine's day dinner on a Saturday night. We were quite excited for the occasion due to the reviews. Although I remember enjoying the food fairly well - we had the cheese plate, some good entrees and a wonderful dessert - I have to say that the noise level ruined it for me. This place seems to be pegged as a "romantic restaurant", however, we could barely hear each other during the meal. We were seated directly next to the bar and my boyfriend had another bar patron standing next to his chair for a good 20 minutes almost talking over him. Our waitress seemed to be overwhelmed and it was very difficult to get her over to the table and we were waiting to order for almost 30 minutes after being seated. So would I return? possibly... but maybe on a week night, and not for an occasion when I'm trying to have a "romantic" meal.
author: Kelly B.

description:
I had an amazing vday dinner here with SO.  It's a charming little Mediterranean restaurant situated in Russian Hill on the corner of Hyde and Green St. 

Our dinner reservation was at 6pm.  We got there a little late but it wasn't that bad.  I suggest you make time for parking since it can be a bit challenging.

We were greeted by warm smiles immediately as we walked in.  One thing nice was that Frascati had a prix fixe dinner that night which helped eliminate my indecisiveness (it's a Libra thing).

First course - Steak Tartare.  Absolutely delicious.  The olive oil, spices, and capers really made this first course dish stand out.  I'm usually not a fan of raw meat but this was super tasty with a crostini.  He had the scallops.  Even though I am allergic to shellfish I will eat this stuff.  These were cooked just right.  Soft, sweet, yet fresh.

Second course- Eggs and Bacon.  Don't let the name fool you but this was definitely unique.  It was a small plate of field greens with thick diced pieces of yummy fried bacon along with an over-easy duck egg.  The duck egg is what made this dish interesting.  As I pierced the yolk it oozed over the bed of greens.  It was yummy.  I enjoyed this dish very much so.  He had Lobster Bisque.  I had to take a couple of spoonfuls of this wonderful soup.  Too bad i'm allergic but I made sure i didn't overdose.

Third course - some type of sea bass.  I wish i remembered the exact name of this dish.  That's what I get for not paying attention (i blame it on the pinot noir which totally complimented my meal). The sea bass was lightly fried w/skin and was also accompanied by wild mushrooms and a creamy polenta. The dish was very good.  He had the lamb.  I'm very picky when it comes to lamb and the way how it's cooked.  This was executed well.  No gamey like taste.  I could totally eat this!

Our server was so nice.  Food and wine was excellent.  A very small yet romantic restaurant.  Atmosphere is more on the quiet side.  No loud boisterous noises here.  Definitely a restaurant to check out in this neighborhood.  I also love how the cable cars pass by.  It's cool watching the tourists peek in through the window watching us wine and dine.
author: Ro C.

description:
Date/Time: Saturday - 8:45pm
Occasion: Date night after a day of moving!
Party of: Two
Location:  Small little corner restaurant.  Reminiscent of something you might see in North Beach. Warm, romantic interior. TINY restroom...get ready to bump your head on the door. :D 
Ordered:  Starters: Russett Potato Gnocchi and Foie Gras Torchon.  Main entrees: Grilled Pork Chop and Fresh Seafood Fettuccine.  Dessert: Artisinal Cheese Platter.
Total incl gratuity: ~$120

I really wanted to love this place!  The reviews seemed impressive and the menu sounded delish.  However, Frascati fell a bit shy of my expectations.  Our reservations were rather late for a Saturday night so we were seated promptly amidst a bustling restaurant.  Our server was slow to greet us, didn't introduce himself, and was mildly attentive.  Disappointing.  I thought the busboy did a better job at being attentive!  

Onto the food.  Appetizers: The foie gras torchon was quite tasty.  It arrived with two pieces of toasted brioche.  The brioche was TDF. I asked for a few more.  After eating five of them, I discovered they were battered in butter.  No wonder those little devils were so good.  :X  The apple currant compote paired nicely with the foie gras.  I had a nibble of the gnocchi however was not impressed.  It was different and packed a lot of flavor although I am not a fan of gnocchi.  The main entrees were good.  My pork chop was seasoned, succulent, and served with all the right ingredients - eggplant puree, cipollini jus, and red onion marmalade.  Good portion.  Not overly small nor overly large.  The fresh seafood fettuccine was just that...fresh!  I could tell the noodle was made in house because it was fine and "eggy".  The seafood in the fettuccine was plentiful and also very fresh.  The pesto was quite inviting.  Of course having a cheese plate on the menu, I had to complete my meal with an order of that.  I love trying new cheeses, they're always so delightful.  My cheese plate included a p'tit basque (sheeps milk), buenalba (goats milk cheese infused with red wine), tallegio (washed cows milk), and maytag bleu cheese.  I enjoyed all of them however my favorites would have ben the p'tit basque and the maytag bleu.  Both very acerbic however the flavors were eased up by the nuts they were served with.

I'm torn.  I would rate this place a 4 for the food, yet 3 for their service.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and round up.  Guess our server was having an off-night.  Nice place to go around Russian Hill.
author: Jess C.

description: Excellent services! We just went there to wait for our turn in other restaurant and ended up eating in the place. Although it is a little bit pricy... the food is amazing! Dressy not casual.
author: Gian C.

description:
If you have out of town guests visiting and want to take them to a classic San Francisco restaurant....this place is perfect! On a street corner right in the center of beautiful Russian Hill. 

My fiance and I took my parents here and everything we ordered was really excellent. Had some great wine as well and finished off the meal with some amazing bread pudding. 

I highly recommend this place for a date or special occasion as well. Make sure you get reservations a week in advance!
author: Dan L.

description:
Im speechless... it was so good... i dont know where to start.  The food was so good, i couldnt wait to eat it and didnt take any pictures.  

So much to say... lets start at the beginning.  We got there early, the place was packed... I was thinking, uh oh, we will have to wait... nope, the waiter said there was a table waiting for us, he even gave us a choice.  we picked the balcony.  A tiny little space that was both cute and romantic... the lighting was perfect.

On to the food... we got three appetizer, a cheese plate, gnocci and "bacon" (its pork belly).  the pork belly.... divine, it been roasted, the skin was still chewy.  the cheese plate, was wonderful... great way to start a meal.  the gnocci was fresh.

I ordered the ribeye.  to my surprise, it was a pretty big size... cant go wrong with a ribeye, and I was right.  The steak came with a bread salad, heirloom tomatoes and best of all a lot of blue cheese.  The blue cheese went so well with the steak, I would have never thought.  

My friend ordered the pasta.  It was spicy and had a very strong olive flavor.  I cant really figure out how they did it, since I didnt see that many olives in the dish.  

And now, the best part.... the dessert.... I dont think ive had such good dessert at a restaurant in a long time.  we ordered the  bread pudding with hazelnut ice cream, panna cotta and one scope of the chocolate peanut butter ice cream.  To my surprise, i think I liked the chocolate PB ice cream the most.  Since they use PB in the ice cream, the ice cream was so rich, creamy and think, it was not really like ice cream at all.  The bread pudding was a chocolate flavor bread pudding, and it was delicious, went so well with the hazelnut ice cream.  the panna cotta was light and but you can really taste the vanilla.

Anyways... loved it.. loved it loved it....  i wanna go back.. again and again...
author: Janet S.

description: This restaurant deserves 5 stars, no question!  It is absoutely adorable inside!  The food is off the charts good (I recommend any of the pastas).  Service is very friendly, and I just loved the atmosphere of the whole place.  Definitely an intimate setting.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Mary S.

description:
This place is fantastic. Cute little gem with great ambiance and neighborhood charm. We started with some fantastic appetizers - the gnocchi was to die for. Entrees included some very good Halibut and a unique Pea puree, lamb and a very good roast chicken. And for dessert - well you could go here just for dessert. Black and white chocolate bread pudding with a giant scoop of hazelnut icecream. Wow. Or peanut butter icecream that was so rich you couldn't stop! 

Can't wait to go back.
author: Lara M.

description: Absolutely amazing from the food to the ambience. Perfect date spot. Russian Hill has some great, charming restaurants that I highly recommend for a first date, as you will surely impress. I had the striped sea bass, absolutely delish.
author: christina C.

description:
Definitely a favorite.  This is THE spot you dreamt of eating at when you saw San Francisco in your local travel magazine.  

Let's do the math:

Tiny restaurant  with upscale feel: + 1
Tree lined street with cable car in  great neighborhood: + 1
A vanguard of the often imitated, seldom mastered, Californian cadre: +4
Yes, parking sucks: -1
Overall Score: 5

The other Russian Hill Restaurants (even 1550) aren't even in the same ballpark.

Do yourself a favor and request a window table.  Whatever you did wrong will be forgiven.
author: Calvin N.

description: This is the restaurant that you've always wished you could find when you are traveling...great food, service and atmosphere.
author: Caroline L.

description:
What a great restaurant! Cozy, bustling with a great SF crowd, and delicious food! I found the service a bit stiff, and then non-existent but enjoyed our dinner nonetheless. 

It was fully packed at 9pm (which is when they stop seating), so reservations are a must.

The bathroom is smaller than a closet, and if you live in the city, probably something you have seen before, but for our out of town guests, they were amazed by it.

Food was delicious and scrumptious. We enjoyed the Ciopinni, Stone Fruit Bruschetta, and Grilled Bread salad as apps for 4 people. Decent portions and we didn't finish it all. 2 of our guests were not seafood lovers and they enjoyed the Ciopinni very much.

For dinner we had the chicken, halibut and ribsteak. All well prepared and well enjoyed.

For dessert we shared the Chocolate bread pudding, while none of us cared for the bread pudding (it was more of a brownie taste/texture) the ice cream topping was divine.

They have loft style seating that overlooks the kitchen, best to try and reserve this during your reservation. We noticed the seats were full until 9:30pm, so you need primo reso time to get in on the action.
author: Sara G.

description:
Wow, this place is fantastic. The only things keeping it from 5 stars are my lackluster dessert experience (more on that later) and touch-and-go service.

But I'll start with the good parts. The restaurant has a really cozy neighborhood vibe. On a Monday night around 7:30, three of us dined upstairs without a reservation. But it was packed. 

We started with the gnocchi and foie gras - both were delicious, but the foie gras was truly memorable. It was topped with a black sea salt that made my tastebuds sing! 

I moved on to an incredible pork chop with some sort of apple awesomeness for my entree. I tried a friend's lamb, which was also so tender and delicious.

Our finale was the black and white bread pudding, which I envisioned as delicious, but this was the only point at which the meal fell down. The hazelnut ice cream was very good, but the pudding was dry...really disappointing.

The only other imperfect note is service-oriented. The waitress was nice I guess, but overly stuffy - she had a weird vibe. She kept thanking us for every order and request we placed - kind of bizarre. 

That said, yum, yum, yum, this place measured up to expectations - what a gem!
author: Kiesha R.

description: Been here a couple of times and every time has been amazing! Great location, incredible food and a pleasant atmosphere. The bread pudding is as everyone says, delicious! The wine list is excellent and the service is friendly. The first time I came here I had dessert and drinks at the bar, which was a lot of fun. My friend and I made conversation with some of the other patrons at the bar, and the bartender was very outgoing and talkative. I have also come here in a larger group and sat in the dining room for a late night graduation dinner. Everything was amazing except we did feel rushed by our waiter to leave. We had reservations for  9:30 (can't remember exactly) and after sitting down and ordering wine and appetizers we were told we needed to order by 10pm because the kitchen was closing. At this point we had already built up a $200 + tab and we were a little miffed that 30 min after sitting down we were starting to feel rushed. Believe me I waited tables and bartended for 6 years, so I know how frustrating it is when you have a lingering table. However, if you have a large party that has taken the last reservation for the night you just prepare yourself for a late night and hope your gratuity reflects the good service you give and the inconvenience of having to stay late. But even with that little mishap, I would still highly recommend this place for great food, service and atmosphere!
author: Florence M.

description: Wonderful ambience: perch on the top floor to observe some capable line cooks.  The dishes are fine, especially the funghi bruschetta and pork chop.
author: Dana B.

description:
Corner of Green and Hyde
Right on the cable car run
Charming Italian, 2 1/2 story restaurant (split floor seating)
From the second floor, one can smell the great smells waifing (?) from the kitchen.
Starters included bacalao fritters, foie gras, and green lentil soup.
My grilled sardine salad was good.
The grilled pork chop was delish, and the blue nose bass over couscous and Brussel sprouts was okay, but the homemade parpadelle with spinach and wild boar sugo was very tasty.
Everything was presented beautifully.
The service was good.
Wine and beer only; the wines by glass were good.
Desserts included a dynamite bread pudding and affogato.
author: Rosquete B.

description: Great food, very cozy, dark-lit, romantic atmo.
author: Pasha B.

description:
My supermodel diet passed away last night at  7p.m. at Frascati in Russian Hill.  It leaves behind aspirations of being comfortable in hot tubs and dreams of developing killer abs.  It is survived by a nice memory of being seated at an intimate window table (sans reservations), a very full stomach, and a slight guilt complex.

Leading up to my diet's untimely death, I enjoyed the steak tartare ($12), gnocchi ($9), and 1/2 roasted chicken with fingerling potatoes ($20).  Just a quick glance at my date's rack of lamb even caused me to gain an extra pound.

A nice bottle of Merlot, well past the recommended heart-healthy portion (cheers!), helped ensure that this diet will not be rising from the ashes in the near future.

I am sad that my diet died so prematurely, but it leaves me wondering - how can diets survive, when fabulous restaurants like this one exist?  Frascati, I beg you, please either stop making everything on your diverse menu sound so appealing, or buy me a bigger pair of jeans.
author: Janney B.

description:
Food (3): Solid, if somewhat unimaginative.
Service(5): Warm, attentive, prompt.
Atmosphere(4): Cozy, but a little loud.
Price(3): A bit pricey. An appetizer, main + shared dessert and share bottle of wine = $65 per head.

Overall: I'd be happy to go there if someone suggested it, but, given the plethora of dining choices in the Bay Are, would not return otherwise.
author: Yogi B.

description:
They say Disneyland is the happiest place on Earth. I beg to differ. My vote goes to Frascati. Dine here and you will be immersed in a pretty room full of of beaming people eating perfect food served by friendly, knowledgeable, unstuffy waitstaff.

One rendition of perfection was the following meal my BF and I enjoyed (emphasis on JOY) the other night:

*Shared starter of carrot bisque soup. Prepared, well...perfectly. Exactly the right texture, nice little swirl of cream in the center, lightly herbed to accent, not overwhelm.

*My main was a maple-glazed Muscovy duck breast atop a bed of spaetzel and trumpet mushrooms in a huckleberry sauce. It was....what's the word I'm looking for? Oh yes, PERFECT.

*His main was a super juicy pork chop with braised fennel and a tomato apple compote. Delicious!

*Our personable, with-it waiter suggested a wonderful Gewurztraminer to pair with my meal and a superb Pinot Noir for the chop. It's repetitive, yes, but they were perfect matches. 

*I had the affogato for dessert (espresso with vanilla bean ice cream & chantilly cream - tastes even better than it reads) and he had the baked apple cobbler a la mode. 

The cobbler was such a hit that as she was exiting, a sweet little old lady who looked to be about 90 years old and weighed maybe 90 lbs. as well, stopped at our table, pointed at the cobbler and said "Isn't that delicious? I had one and half". She smiled like a kid (well, at Disneyland) and went merrily on her way.

Happy, happy, joy, joy! Frascati will always be an E-ticket ride for me.
author: wendella a.

description: Had a great dining experience here with my husband for our anniversary. The food is awesome and reasonable for sf in my opinion. I had the pork chop and my husband had the duck, so delicious!!! Highly recommend for a special evening!
author: Cristen L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came to Frascati for another one of our monthiversaries... Definitely good, but not great. Everything was a little above average: service, food quality, ambiance. It's definitely cramped but luckily, we were seated upstairs away from the crowd.

I would recommend, but it's not on my list of restaurants to go to again.
author: Han C.

description:
C and I had the most fantastic experience at Frascati!  Afterwards, we literally stumbled the whole two blocks home and fell asleep with all of our clothes on (this is rare), in a blissful state of food coma.

Upon arriving, we were seated in a cozy little spot next to the wine bar, and our waiter masterfully helped us choose our entrees and a jammy red.  The food arrived, and we had no choice but to exclaim between bites.  The duck breast with huckleberry compote was rich and tender.  The lamb was juicy and cooked rare to perfection with marinade and spices. By the time we finished the chocolate bread pudding, we were surrounded by a halo of heavenly warmth.

A warning - do not make plans to go out after Frascati. Your friends will wonder why you've become such flakes.  This restaurant lives up to its hype and its comfort food will take you down quicker than a Thanksgiving turkey dinner.
author: Nicole G.

description:
So far this is my favorite restaurant in SF. Granted, I've lived here less than a year, but I have a feeling this place will remain among my favorites. The food is DELICIOUS and the ambiance is great. And it's location on Hyde St is so idyllic... it is the perfect place for a date. I got the Figs appetizer dish and it was heavenly. I had the risotto, also fantastic. The service was great. Was there on the early side so got a table on the second floor, tucked away by the window. 

I also think it's a great value. Incredible food and ambiance for a fairly reasonable price. This place is pretty much perfect!!!
author: Priya N.

description: Great restaurant in amazing location in Russian Hill.  The food is delicious and unpretentious, the staff a pleasure to interact with, and the ambiance very quaint and relaxing.  A real gem in the neighborhood!
author: Brad P.

description:
For the price, you are much better off going elsewhere. Although I have lived in this neighborhood, and unless you trek all the way down the hill to Columbus and back up there are no other options (which is not a bad idea, since you will have stuffed yourself full of calories). If you don't live in Russian Hill, go somewhere else with better food and less-impossible parking. 

I ended up here at my roommate's mini-high-school-reunion because he was complaining that everyone in the group was coupled up like Noah's Ark. Lo and behold, I arrive and one of the girls was sans-boyfriend. Despite my unnecessarily making an odd number of 7, it wasn't a bad evening.

My mixed greens balsamic was overly sour. I even had a couple of dinner-mates try it to make sure. I have never had a salad dressing that resulted in such a crumpled-up, Warhead face before. 

The maple duck breast entree I had was pretty good, but didn't knock my socks off. Some of my dinner companions said their oxtail bone marrow was the best they'd ever had. The tastiest thing I had all night was the duck-accompanying spaetzle. It was my first time, and I don't like its Italian counterpart, gnocchi, but this was smaller, chewier, more grain-like and I loved it. 

Chocolate brownie: So overrated. I got it because that's what #1 and #2 review snapshots were about. Nothing special, and I hate you for ruining review snapshots for me. 

Service was fantastic, especially our main server dude. He knew everything about the ingredients and how every dish was prepared. The lady who served us dessert seemed in a hurry to get home, but totally understandable since our group was the last to leave the restaurant.

Listen, Russian Hill girls: 4 star average, 5 star mode?! Are you trying to move to the Marina? Grow some taste buds and come back to see me when you've learnt from your mistakes.
author: Gloria L.

description:
A genuine treat:  we popped in here last week at the suggestion of Nish N. (and based on the body of enthusiastic local reviews for this place) and were not disappointed.  Word to the wise, it can get crowded, and as we found out, it can be helpful to call ahead to make a reservation, but our service was prompt and attentive, the food exquisite and ample.

I sampled the duck while the dessert lover attacked a mountainous pork chop combination, offset nicely with a glass of recommended syrah.  It's a small, trattoria-like arrangement here, ambient, cozy, with a heady charm.    We enjoyed (like those around us) a leisurely night out here, and to that end, Frascati breathes like an exhale: all warm, inviting, filled with grace and absolutely necessary.
author: Kevin N.

description: I was very disappointed in the restaurant. We had a very important birthday dinner there last week and although the food was fine, the service was very rushed and attitude very cold. Our main course was delivered to the table before two in our party had finished their first course. The bill was delivered at the same time as our dessert. No asking about coffee. The restaurant was more interested in turning the table than making sure we had a nice evening. I will not return.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Another place that's riding off of the momentum of the trendy Russian Hill District. There's a lot of restaurants with the same decor even similar product mix that reside on Hyde street. I guess that's what works so they keep it at it. ;-)

We tried the Gnocchi here which were tasty but it didn't take an expert to taste how much butter was used in preparing the dish (not a fan of butter). It was so rich that i ended up having to walk off my stomach cramps up and down Hyde street. 

Next was the mushroom soup which i have no complaints about i thought it was just right.

Salad was good but salads are generally not a great surrogate measure of the overall quality.

For desert it was the rum cake which was average. Perhaps i ate it too fast and didn't enjoy it the way I should but it just didn't create an impression.

Service here was great overall the waiter was very attentive and wanted to make sure that the person who requested gluten free actually got gluten free food.

Taken everything into consideration and massive bloating after that meal which wasn't big (just full of butter) I'd say this place barely makes it to 3 stars.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description: AMAZING!  Everything tatsted delicious and they have the best panna cotta I have every tried in my life!  Highly recommended.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Don't be scared off by the somewhat cheesy website (hello, Mr. Gucci loafers!) - Frascati is the kind of neighborhood restaurant that you love to find in any city.

It's Intimate, friendly, with carefully prepared dishes, and a friendly and professional staff.  The food is hearty but not heavy, and well-presented.  Everything on the menu sounded so good that it was really hard to choose what to eat.

I started with the foie gras torchon, which was very buttery and rich, in a beautiful cylindrical presentation.  Other appetizers that I tasted were the gnocchi, the mushroom bisque, and the burratta - with my favorite being the burrata, which was a huge portion of of this creamy, luscious cheese.

For my entree, I had the pan-roasted chicken, which was absolutely delicious.  It's an entire half chicken, de-boned, and cooked perfectly with a crisp, savory skin and moist meat.  It will be hard to venture away from this dish the next time it was there, it was that good.

For dessert, we shared the Black & While bread pudding (large portion, plenty for 4 people) - a good choice for bread pudding and chocolate lovers alike.

To be fair, I am not sure that this was their best night, as some of the dishes were a little off in their seasoning - either not enough salt, or too smoky - but I could tell that it would be nearly impossible to have a bad meal here, and overall everything was very good.  I look forward to returning and trying some more dishes - or simply tasting that delectable chicken again.
author: Liz S.

description:
This is the most consistent restaurant in San Francisco.  I come here about once every six months, with people young and old, friends, family, dates, everything.  And everyone leaves impressed.  By this point, I think I've tried everything on their seasonal menus, and have always left impressed.  It says a lot when I'd rather go here than try someplace new...or maybe I'm just afraid of change.  

The service is great.  The waiters aren't afraid to make recommendations and will tell you their favorite things on the menu.  The wine list is a little thin but it's very reasonably priced and has a nice selection of French and Italian wines.  They do not have a full liquor license.

It has the second-smallest bathroom in San Francisco, following just behind Nob Hill Cafe.

Anyway, last night our table ordered the duck, the lamb, and the pork chop.  All three were spectacular.  We knew it was a good sign when the owner came over with our wine and opined that his favorite three things on the menu were...those three things.  I mentioned to him that a year ago I'd ordered the veal carpaccio with orange oil and he said it would be making a reappearance, which means I'm going back.
author: Geoff K.

description: Frascati is a terrific, friendly, neighborhood spot. The food is always reliably good and the service makes you feel right at home.  This is a place to come back to, time and time again.
author: S.K. R.

description: This is one of the numerous excellent neighborhood restaurants in San Francisco. We started with the delicious wild mushroom bruschetta. I had the best roasted chicken dish that I've ever had1 My husband enjoyed his beef pappardelle as well. We finished with a lovely peach-blueberry cobbler. We'll definitely be back!
author: Marie S.

description:
This is a great restaurant. The food was great, the service was amazing!  From the moment we walked in the waiter was very attentive and my glass was never empty. Definitely a must if you live in the neighborhood. I had the rack of lamb, that is a must try!

Guys-this is a great date spot.
author: Krystle M.

description: Frascati is a neighborhood gem, just the kind of place SF is famous for.  It's small and homey, tables packed in an old wooden building.  But the food is outstanding.  We ordered 3 appetizers to share, 3 entrees to share, 4 main dishes (also sampled) and 3 desserts.  Rarely is every item exceptional but in this case they were.  The food was surprising and delicious.  Service was impeccable.  I brought my own wines but their wine list is adequate.  Can't wait to return.
author: Paul Richard M.

description:
All I have to say is Basil Ice Cream.

Yes, I said BASIL ICE CREAM!  

Despite what you might think, it was delightful. It complimented the caramel nectarine tart so well, we almost licked the plate clean. Think vanilla with a light essence of basil.

The entire ambience and meal were fantastic.  An intimate date like atmosphere with low lighting, cosy interior feel and a very friendly and helpful wait staff.
author: Sherry C.

description: I dined @ frascati friday for my girlfriend's birthday .as usual to service was excellent .I was feeling brave because everything I order  there is usually really really good so I tried swordfish . swordfish was good I was a little disappointed because it wasn't as good as the chicken or pork chop but nevertheless it was good.my girlfriend order to skate which is like a stingray type of fish  and she really really enjoyed it .make sure you make reservations that's the biggest tip I can give you .
author: johnny W.

description:
This place is AMAZING, and if I hadn't had one of the zaniest weeks in recent memory, I would have sat down and yelped about it immediately. A week later, this place stands out, both for the service and for the amazing food.

The restaurant is everything that's great about San Francisco: fresh foods, personal service, and the feeling that you're having a warm and unique dining experience.

If you go, you must get the figs. And the brussel sprouts. (I thought I hated brussel sprouts but it turns out that my nine-year-old self does not agree with my present-day self about this important issue.) Oh, and you must also try the honey glazed duck. The sad part (maybe) is that they change their menu frequently, so these dishes may not be available for you. I don't do regular desserts anymore, so they made a delicious fruit cup of figs (yum, a repeat) and some other fruits.

Many thanks to the wine-buyer and our waitress for a truly memorable evening. Be sure to try the table upstairs with the view of the kitchen.
author: Ellie P.

description: Food was great (I recommend the cheese platter), and the wait staff was very nice. The only complaint was that the place closes too early, so you feel bad staying after closing hour because you're keeping the wait staff truly 'waiting'.
author: Hemant S.

description: Ambiance, food, upscale neighborhood feel all fantastic. We generally go there for special occasions and it feels special. No corkage fee if you order a bottle of wine and want to bring a second. The wait staff would be the only not perfect thing, not the friendliest, but not too bad and everything else exceeds expectations so it still nets out at 5 stars for me.
author: Janice M.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here for years and finally made it last night for my fiance's birthday.  The restaurant itself is super cute and in a great location (Hyde at Green).  (Can I just say how much I wish I lived in Russian Hill?  I love how the restaurants are all tucked away on cute corners...I try to live in the neighborhood every time I move, but it never works out...anyways, I digress...)

We were seated upstairs and I immediately noticed how many couples were on dates.  The atmosphere is very romantic (warm, good lighting, etc.).  We started with the cheese plate, which was beautifully plated and incredibly delish!  I ordered the duck that I had read so much about and fiance ordered the pesto pasta.  The duck was good (juicy and tender), but I have to say the pesto pasta was way way better -- I will be ordering tht next time.  We shared the gynormous bread pudding with hazelnut ice cream (which was awesome and tasted like chocolate cake -- you MUST order this!).  

Some of the reviews mention that the place is overpriced -- I disagree.  Yes, it may be more pricey than some restaurants, but the price is commensurate with the level of service and dining.  Our bill came out to $100 (without tip) for 1 app, 1 dessert, 2 entrees and 2 glasses of wine, which was actually lower than I expected.  The service was perfect, by the way.  I think I found my new favorite spot!
author: Mitzi C.

description:
What is Frascati good for?

A whole bunch of BAD ATTITUDE.  

You should only eat here if you want to get yelled at by the service staff for them throwing away your to go box.

This is one of those cases where I would give ZERO stars but yelp won't let me. 

After a lovely time stuffing ourselves with savories and bread, I could not eat one more bite of my rack of lamb. One order supplies five chops. I couldn't finish my dinner so I asked for a box. So did my halibut girlfriend and my pork chop girlfriend. 

Halibut and Pork Chop got their boxes right away. When I inquired about my to go box, I was told that it was waiting for me at the door. A few moments later one of the service staff came over and said, "I asked you if you wanted a box and you said, 'No.'" I was shocked because Halibut had asked for a box for both of us and when the service staff took my plate I said that I wanted a box. Perhaps he heard what he wanted to hear. 

He did not apologize. He said that it was MY FAULT for him hearing that I said that I didn't want a box. He basically called me out in front of the whole restaurant saying that I was making up the fact that I wanted /didn't want a box. I had TWO LAMB CHOPS and 75% of my ratatouille left on my plate. I arranged it to look pretty on my plate. WHO WOULD THROW AWAY $20 leftovers??? Obviously he would.

I was shaking mad and asked to talk to the manager. The manager came over and said that he regretted the situation and offered to make a PASTA dish or a BREAD PUDDING dessert for me to take home. YEAH RIGHT. Like a $5 dish will make up for my bruised ego and $50 dinner. 

He did not once apologize for the situation and he did not once offer to have the service staff come over to apologize for me. 

The only consolation that I have for tonight is that I was with ten girlfriends who will no doubt spread the bad news of Frascati far and wide. 

Below is a review of the food that we ordered:

The duck trio was okay. You need to eat a lot of bread to get it all down.

The risotto was tender but needed seasoning.

The gnocchi was lovely with all the beans and veges.

The seared ahi tuna definitely needed the olive condiment to make it work.

The rack of lamb was slightly over cooked; I asked for medium rare. The ratatouille was tasty and tender. 

The pork chop was a little too sweet.

The steak was a little tough. 

The halibut was just right. The vegetables were a perfect complement to the fish. 

The pasta was bland yet al dente. 

The chocolate bread pudding had a nice caramel chew to it; however, bread pudding is supposed to be soft; like pudding. 
...........................................................................................................................

Today is 7/28/07. One day after my majorly unpleasant experience at Frascati, Pork Chop girl got a call back from the restaurant manager. He left a message apologizing for last night, said that he spoke to the employee who made me feel awful about my non-lamb, and asked that we come back so that he can change our opinion about Frascati.

Hm.

Thanks for the message, but I really don't feel like going back anytime soon. 

You get one legit star for the fact that you left a message and told us that you spoke to the employee about his impolite behavior.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
A great date restaurant.  Small, cozy, romantic and welcoming.  Great cheese plate, great charcutery plate, and consistently wonderful entrees.  Usually easier to get last-minute reservations (or a walk-in table) at than other Russian Hill superstars like 1550 Hyde (right down the street).  Still I'd recommend reservations Thursday-Saturday, or any day after 8:00.  Wine by the glass list is serviceable, but could use some expansion.  Service is consistently awesome---friendly, knowledgable, prompt.

This is one of those places I'm mad at myself for not going more often.
author: Ben P.

description:
My friend brought me here for my birthday and needless to say, I was still raving about it for nearly a month after. We loved it so much, we ended up bringing a group of our friends to the restaurant soon after. The food was delicious, the service was on point and we enjoyed ourselves. The food was fresh and I don't remember having any complaints about any of the food, since it was late last summer when I went. I would definitely come back. I can't wait to see what they're serving up now.

Great place for a date and a perfect meal.
author: Jennifer T.

description: This is the best restaurant I've been to in a long time. Great amiable waitstaff, small cozy neighborhood atmosphere, and tasty well crafted food. We went hog wild! Had foie gras appetizer, mushroom app (the least interesting dish), then the pork chop (wow what a tasty large portion with potato spaetzl and other yummy things mixed in). Then topped it off with the caramelly chocolatey bread pudding. Amazing! And the waitstaff picked excellent wine for us base on what kind of wine we like and what we were ordering. Can't wait to go back.
author: Marissa A.

description:
This is a perfect date spot or place from friends to gather. The food was the best I've had in months! We happened upon Frascati, while strolling through Russian Hill. The service is very attentive. 

I had the roasted artichoke salad to start with and the grilled base. Both were delicious. My boyfriend had the gnocchi to start with (highly recommend) and the rack of lamb. The chocolate bread pudding was sooo good! Everything on the menu looked wonderful. 

Excellent ambiance.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
We live in the neighborhood and walked to Green and Hyde.
Noisy, dark couldn't see the plates, supposed to be romantic but now we know. Barely tolerated staff, once water is on the table, forgotten. Barely tolerant of 13 year old well behaved children who after a while got bored, why not?
Wine from Lodi, white, terrible, over priced and recommended by staff, evidently never tried it. Received the bill with 25% gratuity added, circled and enforced. Gave up, never again, pity the poor tourists.
author: Erven T.

description: I thought the food was very good as was the service.  They have a room upstairs toward the back that looked very nice for small groups...up to about 10.  We were unable to get our preferred time of 6:30, but saw lots of empty tables when we arrived.  Very curious.
author: pat m.

description:
Do you ever have one of those weeks where, no matter where you go, you seem to get shitty service?  (And so you wonder--all damn week--whether last night's spinach is still stuck in your teeth; whether your deodorant has stopped your pits from reeking; whether your skirt has been perpetually stuck in your pantyhose...)

I went to Frascati on the tail end of a week of bad service, hoping to bring it to an end.  That didn't happen.  Our server was mostly absent; irritatingly chatty when table-side; and slowwwwww.  Not slow in the lazy bistro way--slow in that the-dining-room-is-overcrowded-and-I'm-too-busy-to-refill-your-water way.  I mean, we spent $200--a little attention would've been nice.

But I'm four-starring this place nonetheless.  Let's review why.

First, I didn't order the cheese plate, but it included two of my all-time favorites:  Humboldt Fog & St. Andre.  Plus 10 bazillionjillion for Frascati.  

We did order two other appetizers:  the fig-prosciutto-blue cheese salad & the heirloom tomato-couscous-feta salad.  Although both were good, the fig salad far outshone its companion:  The figs were juicy & meaty, dripping with balsamic vinegar & wrapped in generous cuts of a thin, salty prosciutto that neither overtook the figs nor was lost in the acidity of the balsamic.  Really well-done.

For my entree, I chose a crusted halibut (also generously portioned!) set atop fava beans and topped off with a "mushroom salsa."  Although I found the beans unremarkable, that mushroom salsa had me at hello--it was a sweet, rich chop-chop of multiple mushrooms that just dissolved in my mouth.  

As for dessert, I first tasted the "pavlova," which actually was just a cookie-like meringue topped with powdered sugar, mixed berries, and fresh whipped cream.  If you know what real pavlova is (a SOFT-baked meringue, not a meringue cookie! UGH!), don't bother with Frascati's version.  

But then I tasted the famed chocolate bread pudding.  Believe everything you read about that one.   

Overall:  I'd order the cheese plate; fig salad; and the chocolate bread pudding ... and maybe have a few words with the waiters?
author: Ann M.

description:
Our manager took our entire sales team here for dinner one night to celebrate our production levels. 

I was floored by this place. This totally quaint and understated little hole in the wall on the corner of Hyde street serves some of the best food I've ever tasted. 

Their menu changes seasonally and they have two of the most memorable dishes I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing: White truffle gnocchi and pork tenderloin. Though their pork comes on and off the menu, the gnocchi stays on there for a good amount of time. Don't get me wrong, so much of their menu is delicious, and the prices are quite reasonable compared to some other restaurants of the same caliber quality. 

If you're ever in San Francisco and looking for a great dining experience, I HIGHLY recommend Frascati.
author: Arthur K.

description: Fantastic date night, great food with a neighborhood feel. Waitress was awesome and even chased us down when my finance forgot her purse! -she ran half a block, uphill, to save the night. Anyplace with that quality of people deserves to be 5 stars.
author: Nick M.

description:
With all the over-hyped, wait-two-months-for-a-reservation, SF restaurants, Frascati deserves serious accolades.  Had wondered about this place but until recently hadn't had the opportunity to try it.   Sooo glad I did.  Just strolled in the other night with no reservations and was seated immediately - at a cute little table right in the window to watch the cable cars roll by.  

The food, wine and service especially rivaled anywhere I have eaten in the city.  The pinot they have by the glass is amazing and our server kept offering us tastes of all the wines to make sure we had the glass we liked best.

The bread salad was incredible.  I would go back just for this.  Also amazing were the charcuterie plate, the cheese platter (love Humboldt fog), and the special of fillet over risotto.  

Parking may be a bitch - so take the cable car or a cab.  Or ... move in to my apt which is a block and a half away!  (Don't worry, I'm moving out of it...  ;)
author: Brad C.

description:
Good - not great.

I have been going to and sending my best freinds to Frascati since I moved into the neighborhood in 2003. 

The food was always great, but it was the service and attitude that made it #1 on my list for an important night where I knew everything was going to be just perfect. A great date place and friendly, reliable place I could trust for important business dinners as well.

I made my reservation, asked for a specific waiter and table; "fine we'll see you then."

I showed up on time exactly,  not knowing it had been recently sold, I still saw a lot of familiar faces when I walked in and felt Ok, but the waiter wasn't working there on Fridays anymore (how can that be?), the reservation upstairs - expressly asking for a table upstairs - was not available (was I in the right place?), no hospitality was offerred for our 30 minute wait - I never waited for more than 5 minutes before under same circumstances, and if I did one of the fine folks working there would offer  a taste of wine for the wait. I decided to go across the street for a glass of wine to wait for 30 minutes, 25 minutes later just as I am paying my bill across the street  I get a phone call, "Are you coming back?" with a little tiny atttitude. 

It was 9:00 now and the place was thinning out a bit. I still did not get the table I wanted, bread took 10 minutes to find its way to us at least, no friendly looks, the FEEL was very different. The wait staff regulars were going about the business of serving and the mechanics of ordering and so forth was average. The menu was different (no more short ribs sadly) but the choices were interesting ,our selection was cooked perfectly and the presentation was great. I had Cod and my guest had the lamb chops -  exellent too. Bread pudding, my favorite, was a little too crispy in some places, but still very good. Food = good, above average for sure. The wine list looked smaller, not sure but it had good choices as normal.

So in my humble opinion but also as someone who has eaten at Frascati over 3 years and maybe 30 times the food was good and the service was fine. You need more than good food and service in this class, you need great service. I don't go out of my way in SF to find good food, its easy. I do, and will in the future, for service. 

Its a very GOOD neighborhood place with class. I probably won't go out of my way to go again. The new owners have some team building or something to do.  Good luck, I'd rather hold on to my memories than build others that will bring me lesser joy!
author: JX C.

description: Frascati was a random pick off of yelp for me, but I was pleasantly surprised! This quaint neighborhood gem was just what I was looking for to take my mother to dinner while she was in town. Classy, proper service,  and a delicious menu all played perfectly into the setting. We sat in a small upstairs/loft area just over the kitchen where we were able to observe and smell the kitchen. It seriously whet's the appetite. The food was delicious, the suggested wine paired perfectly, and desert was the nail in the coffin. All in all and excellent dining experience, which I must say is something of a rarity these days.
author: Ryan G.

description:
If Frascati is a neighborhood restaurant, then you're in a damn great neighborhood.  The place may be considered cute, the servers are attentive, although mine could have cut back on the cologne. But he was very nice.

I constructed a four course meal that was modestly priced given the overall quality of the ingredients, Tomato bisque was nice but a bit too acidic to the point where the taste of tomato was somewhat masked.  On the other hand bread salad was all that a salad should be: light, refreshing, plentiful.  The pork chop in my main course was tender,  properly cooked, and tasty.  Unfortunately, the meat had to compete with some very acidic cabbage (vinegary).   

A seasonal pumpkin pie was not at all remarkable, however, the grand marnier cream that came with it was fantastic.  

Overall, a very nice meal in a very nice place.
author: David D.

description:
- good food
- good service
- they got a dish wrong, but gave us desert for free and a complementary gnocchi while waiting
- good wines
- open kitchen is cool but the smell stays on clothes
author: Nick S.

description:
What I tried:
1. Calamari... delicious
2. cheese plate... delicious
3. Seared duck... delicious
4. Rack of Lamb... DE-LI-CIOUS

The cook really understands how to bring the flavors out. Words would not be enough to really describe why the food was good. There was a delicate balance of flavors that made the meals very enjoyable, but not overwhelming. Each plate I tried was truly a wonderful balance. All the meats were cooked perfectly too.

Upside... this place rocks. Downside... parking.
author: Zeel J.

description:
Very charming and excellent food at Frascati. I had the gnocchi for an appetizer and the scallops for a main course. I thought they were both delicious, albeit small portions. My friends had 2 different kinds of salads for their appetizers, and one had the duck and the other had the gnocchi as a full course - their portions were larger than mine, so I guess it was just luck of the draw. Although I loved my serving of gnocchi, my friend said that she thought hers was grainy and dense. To each their own. 

The service was great, too. Attentive but not intrusive. 

The restaurant makes efficient use of its small vertical space. It's crowded without feeling claustrophobic.
author: Melinda K.

description:
I highly recommend it! 

***Memorable***
*Great food & Wine (Divine) 
*Elegant Ambiance, excellent lighting, & cozy  (I would dress up) 
*Great, knowledgeable & intuitive waitstaff
*The whole meal was divine
*Highly Recommend:
Cocoa Dusted Bison Carpaccio, Truffled Gnocchi & Rack of Venison

As much as I would like to describe it in detail, I can't...It's hard to recreate the memory of that meal. You have to see for yourself :) 

Tip: Make reservations
       Parking in Russian Hill is scarce
author: Christina D.

description:
Everything was very good here.  Slow, but when the food and wine are good, you hardly notice.

I shall start with two words:  Bread Pudding.  Pause.  Breathe.  Yes, it was really that good.  And I am not that much of a bread pudding fan.  

Next, I turn to the wine list.  There is a reason they have Wine Spectator awards on their walls.  The wine list is impressive and there are a bunch of choices in the more moderate range.  We settled on the Rafanelli Zin, which upon tasting, brought an immediate smile to my face and relaxed all the muscles in my back.

The chicken was good, but simple.  The porkchop was delicious though the roasted pepper sauce on top wasn't necessary given how good the pork was.

Working my way to the start of the meal, the gnocchi was quite good, though a bit heavy, and the figs with prosciutto and blue cheese were drizzled in a fig balsamic reduction sauce of some sort...damn good.

Anyway, a top notch, Cal-Italian place near my hood.  Will definitely go back.
author: Zac A.

description:
I haven't been here in so long, I'd forgotten how amazing it is!  A couple girlfriends and I went super early on a Saturday night (5:45 reservation) and got the best seat in the house, the corner window.  It is so perfect for people watching and taking in the neighborhood.  Russian Hill just epitomizes San Francisco charm.

We loved every dish we ordered.  The burrata was incredible and went way too fast.  We split it three ways and decided we each should have ordered our own.  We wizened up and each got a watermelon and ricotta salata though.  OMIGOD.  It has pistachios and mint and balsamic goodness.  We wanted to lick our plates.

Then, for our mains, my lades both got the Halibut, which they loved.  I got the Fettuccine with Seafood and Anchovy pesto  Yum!  It was super rich, but divine.

Finally, dessert.  Good god!  The Warm Black and White Chocolate Bread Pudding is to die for!!!!  And, it is a pretty big portion.  We three split it and couldn't even finish, which is unusual for us.  Keep it in mind.

And, keep this place in mind, too!
author: Melissa M.

description:
figs, bread salad, duck, bread pudding. A hearty red wine. You will leave full and happy.

warning: parking is awful. Take a cab or park down in the lots on Polk and walk up.
author: hunter w.

description:
Solid 4. Thoroughly enjoyed this place! It didn't blow my socks off - but my expectations were already high - and it didn't disappoint.

The food:
- For appetizers, we each ordered the watermelon / feta / mint / pistachio salad. Flavors were great. One complaint would be that the "goods" (the feta, mint, and pistachio) were used sparingly. In other words, there was a whole lotta naked watermelon on that plate. Again - the flavors were great and everything was fresh and pretty, we just wished there had been more.
- For entrees, we each ordered the maple leaf duck breast. It really was fantastic. If you don't like your meat rare - be forewarned that this comes juicy! The flavoring on the skin itself was wonderful and the consistency was perfect! I cleared my entire plate :)
- For dessert, we shared the white and black chocolate bread pudding with hazelnut ice cream. It was good. I don't think it was as good as all the other reviews led me to believe.. but I enjoyed it. I probably wouldn't order it again (it's a heavy ending), but I could recommend it to chocolate-lovers.

Overall - a solid 4. Quite tasty and all-around enjoyable. Would return :)
author: Helen D.

description:
Located in Russian Hill right next to a cable car stop, Frascati is the quintessential San Francisco experience.  As soon as you walk in, the warm yellow walls, intimate neighborhood atmosphere, subtle jazz music playing in the background and bustling open kitchen immediately arouse your senses to acknowledge, "I know I'm gonna have a good time tonight," and that's even before trying the food!

Recommendations to start:

The gnocchi with white truffle oil is simply the best.  The texture has a very, very slight bite to it which is exactly how I love my gnocchi rather than the overdone "why-couldn't-they-take-this-out-a-minute-or-two-sooner" feel offered at other places.  It's typically served with sweet corn mixed with seasonal veggies such as fava beans, morel mushrooms, asparagus or summer squash.  

Grilled asparagus -- how great can grilled asparagus be, right?  Well Frascati somehow found the perfect confection by tossing it with olive oil, a mushroom cous cous and parmesan cheese.  Very light and satisfying.

The bread salad is good, again very light but flavorful with the feta cheese and kalamata olives, but I also like the regular mixed green salad mainly because they toss it with fresh strawberries (and pistachios) and I was pleasantly surprised how the sweet yet sometimes bitterness of the fruit livened up what could have been a plain salad.  I've never seen strawberries on salads so they deserve my kudos for coming up with something original.

Main dishes: 

Their pork dishes are truly the best.  Having grown up not eating pork, I always ordered halibut, chicken or steak (which are excellent as well) but after taking occassional bites off my boyfriend's plate and building up to practically eating the entire dish, I finally resolved to ordering my own and have never gone back.  Their rigatoni with pork sugo has the perfect yin and yan balance -- light yet rich, firm yet tender, sweet yet salty.  Being carb conscious I usually never order pasta as a main but this is worth the extra 30 minutes on the eliptical.

The pork tenderloin with sausage, roasted peppers and basil farro (a grain similar to barley) and pork chop with figs and pancetta are also wonderful.  My family, who also is pork adverse, are now fans of these dishes.
