I give it thumbs up on all fronts - food, service and ambiance.  I can't wait for another special occassion to go back (or when the economy turns :-)
author: kim c.

description:
3.5 stars. I wanted to like this place more. Drove up here from S. bay for my birthday dinner, so maybe my expectations were too high. 
Smiling host seated us immediately at a window table. Our server was initially very friendly and engaging but became increasingly more distracted/distant as evening wore on. Ex. asked us if we wanted more coffee, but turned and left before we could respond--odd.
--Cheese plate had a good selection, came with nuts, chutney, slices of apple, fig and dried apricot, honey drizzle.
--Gnocchi appetizer was meh. I've had much better.
--Roasted pear salad was tasty, but nothing special. Plus, I was imagining succulent, soft slices of pear; instead the pear was presented in hard, melon-balled scoops. (Should have gone with the duck confit salad).
--Pork chop was cooked perfectly, very tender. Didn't care for the accompanying apple salsa, but the potatoes with bacon vinaigrette were quite good.
--Chocolate bread pudding is a thumbs down :( This is a drier bread pudding, with an oddly chewy texture (reminded me of bagged marshmallows). 
Restaurant is cozy and charming. There is a second floor, and the balcony looks perfect for a date-night dinner. If this were my neighborhood eatery, I'm sure I would come here often and be quite pleased. I don't think I would recommend this place for a special occasion dinner though. While the food was presented beautifully, the flavors are just okay. Plus, there's no cocktail menu--I knew this going in, but it's still disappointing.
author: Ann A.

description:
My favorite resturant in San francisco for a nice quited (and romantic) dinner.  Service is stellar, food is consistently near perfect and the atmosphere say casual elegance.

Don't forget to get the bread pudding!
author: Dan G.

description: Quite simply one of the finest restaurants that my wife and I have ever experienced.  I cannot give any higher compliment.
author: Morgan B.

description:
Frascati may be the best restaurant in San Francisco. Don't tell anyone!

UPDATE: Changed from 5 to 3 stars.
I used to be a kool-aid drinker for this place.... but after a very disappointing meal there recently, I have to say that it's fallen off my list.  I'll probably go back once more to see if they have gotten back on track.  What a shame....
author: Amalia S.

description:
alright, so even though I was 20 minutes late for my reservation (finding parking is a bitch) the host was still really nice, and seated us right away. Ok, I love the ambiance at this place.....small, intimate(but not in a lovey dovey romantic way), and has good lighting (the women know this is really important). 
First let me say the waitstaff rocks....not pushy, no attitude, just really friendly and nice and can actually answer questions about the menu. I wanted the duck, and didn't know which wine to have with it and our waiter was great in suggesting some really nice wines. 
The dessert was equally as good, a butterscotch chocolate tart. Yummy.
author: Emily L.

description: I REALLY enjoyed this place.  I wasn't hungry enough for dinner, but I stopped in for a glass of wine and ended up ordering the gnocchi and the broccolini.  The food was really good.  But, what made the experience so positive was the service.  Between the host (possibly the manager?) and the bartender, I felt like I was the only person in the restaurant.  They gave me a lot of attention and were both so friendly that I wanted to keep ordering so that I could stay longer!  ha!  So...I did!  I ordered the bread pudding.  And I'll leave it at this:  HEAVEN!  I'm looking forward to coming back for a full dinner!
author: Susan L.

description:
My old neighborhood restaurant.  I'd rate it 4.5 stars.  
I used to eat there all the time -- frequently even by myself at the bar.  The staff is so nice at this place. If you ever see the duck salad on the menu (or any duck for that matter), order it!  The menu changes regularly, so you never know what you'll find.  My other favorite dish of all time is not the bread pudding -- that gets kind of heavy after a while -- but the warm pear tarte tatin.  Ummmm.  The wines are great here too, and they have an excellent tawny port on the dessert menu.
But one important thing -- if you really want to experience this restaurant at its best, the food and service are much better off-peak, that is Sunday - Thursday nights (like most restaurants).
author: Meredith G.

description:
The boyfriend and I have dubbed this restaurant as our go to place for a romantic date. We've decided to at least come here once a year to get away from the technological realm that is Silicon Valley. The service is great; all the servers who even passed by our table (including Brian, the manager) made us feel at home and completely relaxed.
The food is upscale, but not to the point of pretension. The amount is not considered elf food nor is it massive; it's just enough to fill your tummy...and fill your tummy with warm soothing foods that appeal to all the senses. There were no odd ingredients from far away lands, just good old familiar ingredients utilized to their greatest capabilities.
Appetizers:
First time: the gnocchi is delicious. Basilio, our served, suggested it. I just wish there was more of it.

Second time: foie gras torchon. I'm not going to lie, this was my first time trying foie gras. If you let it sit on your toast for a little bit, it becomes this nice warm buttery texture that definitely screams "screw being refined, eat me!"
Main courses:
First time: I had the porkchop at the suggestion of Basilio again. He was right in saying that this was there most popular dish. It was an added plus that he said it's his favorite dish on the menu. It's nice and juicy on the inside, with a nice outer crispiness. Mmm, lip smacking good. (Sorry, I can't remember what the bf had, I'll have to ask)

Second time: Pan-seared dayboat scallops was amazing! Basilio was our server again; he said that for guys it's usually not enough, but for girls like me, it should be just right. Three perfectly cooked scallops atop spinach mashed potatoes. I loved the presentation and the mash went very well with the scallops.
The boyfriend had the duck, and as most reviews have said pretty much said: GET.THE.DUCK!

We also had two glasses each of red wine at the suggestion of Alexandre, another server. I'm just starting to get into wines, but I'm veering more towards French Reds, especially the one Alexandre surprised us with. Delicious.

I was hesitant about writing this review because I'm selfish and I want this restaurant to remain under the radar so I can keep this little gem all to myself. Lol. But I must to let everyone know how awesome this place is.

Definitely taking my best friend here for our date night. YAY!
author: Mary Ann S.

description:
YES: summer corn risotto (yes yes yes), fried chicken
No: a bit loud, a bummer they don't have a full liquor license
author: James R.

description: This place is such a gem! Amazing food, atmosphere, and it's so fun to watch the cable cars go by. It's pretty romantic, but it's also a great place to take parents who are visiting from out of town.
author: C B.

description: Great restaurant on Hyde St. in San Fran.  My wife and I sat on the 2nd floor overlooking the kitchen and the entire restaurant.   Very scenic!  We got caprese salad and a yummy gnocchi appetizer.   My wife had a great pasta entree and I had a nice salmon entree.   We of course ordered the awesome bread pudding based on Yelp reviews.   We also got smores ice cream and that was great also!    Great service too, I think we had 4-5 different employees coming over to us to deliver plates or help us with more water, etc.   I'd go back for sure!
author: CJ F.

description:
Okay. The decor of Frescati makes it a very charming place in Russian Hill. And, we did get in on a Friday night at 8pm with no reservation and no wait. But, I agree, it is over-hyped as the entire meal amongst our group of four was very inconsistent.

I will say that the appetizers were all good. We ordered the burata cheese/tomato appetizer which was nothing too special (I've had more awesome and creamier burata). Then we got the duck confit salad which was very flavorful and great. 

For entrees, we got the pork chop, quail risotto, ribeye, and halibut. The best one out of the group was surprisingly the risotto (very flavorful and creamy). The pork chop was way too dry. The halibut was also dry. Can't remember much about the ribeye so it must have been neither amazing or horrible...just in the middle.

For dessert, we shared the mixed berry dessert, and it was still FROZEN. Like, wtf? Ice cream should be melting in your mouth. It was just weird and awkward. 

I wouldn't come back here again. I'm actually very surprised about the 4.5 overall rating. If you are 4.5, I'd better be drooling and begging for more.
author: Jeanne C.

description: I have never had a bad meal here.  The food is always fantastic, wine is great, and I love the ambiance of the restaurant with the trolley cars rolling by outside.  The only thing that sucks is that the parking garage next door shut down and now parking is a bit of a nightmare.  Great date night spot or birthday dinner spot.
author: s w.

description:
What can I say about Frascati that hasn't already been said?  This has been a regular spot for my fiance and I for years and it has never failed to deliver.  The bread salad, gnocchi and cobbler are our favorites, but really it's impossible to go wrong with anything on their menu.  

The meat is always cooked perfectly, the flavors are exceptional and even the wine has been perfect each time.  To top it all off, the service is consistently impeccable.  Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Overall great experience at Frascati. The staff were in tune to our needs, and the ambiance was just what we were looking for. Definitely a neighborhood gem. Highly recommend the grilled pear salad and also really enjoyed the potato/leek gnocchi and brussel sprouts. Frascati will have to stay in the rotation! Bon Appetit!
author: Renae K.

description:
I was prepared to be quite underwhelmed by my first experience at Fracati and I was very plesantly suprised. We've now been going back for quite some time and I can honestly say, I've never had a disappointing experience. 

The last visit was exceptional. I highly recommend their prawn risotto... almost as good as the lobster risotto from Gary Danko. Almost! 

The prices are not cheap, but I also don't find them to be over the top in expense either. For the type of food they serve and the experiences I've had, I feel that you get your money out of it. Great food in a great neighborhood in a slightly fancy, but not pretentious setting. You'll be fine walking in here in a nice pair of jeans and a nice shirt. I recommend it!
author: Anita B.

description:
A quintessential SF dining experience.  Cozy atmosphere, friendly service, and outstanding food.  I think I had the best pork chop of my life here, and the desserts are wonderful too.

Granted, I was here for a wedding rehearsal dinner and we took over the first floor, so it was noisy and a bit cramped.  I don't know if it's always that way.  That said, the fact that the food was amazing for close to 40 people is remarkable.  The chefs outdid themselves.

You must have the chocolate bread pudding.  Insanely good.
author: Eric T.

description:
I have always been a huge fan of Frascati. It is such a great restaurant to have in the neighborhood but also worth traveling for.

I haven't been to Frascati in quite some time but was happy to see all my favorites still on the menu with some excellent additions. I always start off with the bread salad. My bf said, "Why don't all places make croutons like this?" The bread in the bread salad is soft grilled bread. You don't get that hard crunch but that soft bready texture with the rest of the salad. It's one of my fave salads in the city. They offered a lobster appetizer atop a portebello mushroom. The lobster was sweet and tender.  Entrees include something for everyone - lamb, duck breast, steak, fish, risotto. I always get the duck so I decided to try something new and went with the lamb. I was definitely very happy with my dish. The rack of lamb was cooked to perfection and thick and tender. The steak was also full of flavor and juicy. Portion sizes are great. 

Now for the best thing on the menu - the black and white bread pudding. OMG...not only the BEST bread pudding ever but probably one of the best desserts I have ever had. It was warm, chocolatey and luscious. The homemade hazelnut ice cream paired superbly with the chocolate. I think I could come back just for this!
author: Josephine H.

description:
My girlfriend took me to Frascati for my birthday and we had a great dining experience.  We had a table near the window so we got to see the "cable-car outside the window" view that they advertise on their website.  And the food was really good!

We started with the grilled bread salad and the gnocchi.  When the bread salad came -- we ordered it without olives, and they mistakenly brought out a salad with olives, but they quickly fixed the problem -- it looked more like a caesar salad with lots of croutons.  However, when we ate it, the bread was grilled very nicely and the flavors were very good.  The gnocchi was cooked perfectly and very tasty too, although I wish the gnocchi-to-vegetable ratio was a little bit better!

For entrees, we had the grilled duck breast and the pork chop.  The duck breast came with a nice duck hash and the piece of duck with crispy skin on it was very good, but the breast piece was a little bit underseasoned.  It came with a very good blackberry sauce but a little bit more salt or spice in the duck itself would have been nice.  The pork chop, however, was awesome.  It was a pretty thick piece of meat, but it was suprisingly moist throughout.  The polenta underneath the chop was very tasty and their apple-slaw-ish thing that accompanied the pork was very complimentary.  

We ended with the bread pudding, which was SOOO good.  Even though I had no room in my stomach to eat it, we almost finished it.  It was very chocolately and the bread had a very good consistency.  It wasn't too mushy and bread, ice cream, and sauces all worked very well together.  

When I go back -- and I will be going back -- I would probably have the bread salad and pork chop again, and then give some other good-looking things on the menu a try.  Highly recommended.
author: Pilan C.

description:
What an amazing restaurant! The atmosphere is charming and quaint, and the service is friendly and attentive. But, let's talk about the food . . . .

The gnocchi with truffles is probably the best thing I've ever had in my life. Seriously, the best. The scallops were rich but light, and the lamb was mouth watering. I had no room for dessert, but I ate it anyway. Apple cobbler . . . YUM!

Overall, an amazing experience that I would recommend to anyone. No wonder it is hard to get a reservation!
author: Jamie C.

description:
I know these guys don't need yet another review but i can't help myself.
We had a party of 9 with one person coming only for dessert.  We had bottles of champagne and wine and delicious food.
Risotto with spring peas - holy cow delish. No one around me got a bite because as soon as I started in, I just kept going on it until it was gone.
The cheese plate is always a good choice - don't worry if you're confused about it being before apps and not as dessert - it's just the right amount of amuse bouche to get your juices flowing. Each cheese has a wonderful fruit/sweet pairing. 
The fish I got was amazing - perfectly cooked and just, well, perfect.
And, hello, chocolate bread pudding. They're known for it. They'll never remove it from the menu (we pray). We ordered 8 of them because a die hard coffee fan just had to have an affogato (which she LOOVED). I don't even have to describe it now, do I?

Service was fabulous - we were seated immediately. Not pestered to order but not left to wait to order.  When I requested a dance floor upon which to tap dance (I was feelin' the bubbly) the waiter pointed out that we did have an unused table nearby...
Every server smiled every time I passed them (on the way to the bathroom that's in the basement down some rather steep, slippery stairs for someone wearing new shoes and who's a bit tipsy - but I'm not complaining) and the place was packed - even on a Sunday night!

Next time you want a fancy dinner, go to Frascati - your belly and palate will thank you.
author: Adriene C.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

Foie Gras with sauternes Gastrique, Apple-currant compote with toast.. the best foie gras I've had in a while! (serving size was large for one person)

My boyfriend got the Italian Sausage Risotto- I'm not a risotto fan so I won't comment. He loved it. 

Maple Leaf Duck Breast- They keep the skin on (just a bit), so it's got the fatty taste on a portion of it which is great. The meat itself was perfectly cooked and tender. 

Herb Crusted Rack of Lamb- Full flavor, wasn't gamey at all, was great!!  I definitely will order this next time (this was my boyfriend's plate).  

We sat upstairs overlooking the kitchen.  We felt separated from others and it was quite romantic (perfect for our 3 month!) They have a little corner table in the middle area that faces a window that we'd like to sit next time if it's dark- very good for that romantic-eating-alone feeling!
author: Hannah W.

description: This is such a fabulous restaurant! I lived in Russian Hill in 2008 and went here on several occasions. I would even go with friends just for dessert! The desserts are to die for!! This place holds a special place in my heart, I would love to go back sometime!
author: Carol B.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. It's small and intimate, and on beautiful Hyde Street. But, what stands out the most is the food and the service. The servers here are extremely well trained, know (and love) the menu, know (and love) the wines, and are really good at reading the tables they serve. Does this table want to be left alone or do they want a jovial server that is part of the dinner experience? They can do it all. 

The food, ahhh the food. The gnocchi here is unreal and the chef always prepares it in new ways, yet it always feels light and fresh (which it often doesn't elsewhere). I'm a huge fan of their Bread Salad (simple but delicious), and their steaks/chicken are always cooked to perfection. You also have to order the chocolate bread pudding for dessert. Their wine selection is also eclectic, so ask for recs!

It's perfect for group dinners (just make a reservation), dates, girl's dinners, or even just a quick bite at the intimate bar. My favorite neighborhood spot.
author: Ams T.

description:
great food, great waitstaff, great decor. came with the fam, ate and drank really well for almost 3 hours. 

gnocci app is delish, so is the pork chop entree. friendly and accomodating waitress and host. awesome location too. check it out.
author: Georgia W.

description: OMG...best roast chicken in SF.  Unreal.  Better than even some fried chickens that I've tasted.  Easily the best and I think we will come back many times for this chicken.  How do they do it???!!!  Its just so good.
author: Mark K.

description: 4.5 stars?  Really?  This was my first 4.5 disappointment.  My fatty stomach has always had a good experience with restaurants with 4.5 stars on yelp.  This place is definitely a place for locals.  I decided to drive here and it took over an hour for me to find parking.  I had to park my fat ass on Bay and Hyde which forced me to walk me fat ass up Hyde street.  FML and fuck this 4.5 star rating.  I was looking forward to eating the grilled pork chop.  All the reviews on here say to "try the pork chop" and "its the best pork chop I've ever had."  I am assuming people that ordered this dish and claimed this was the best pork chop ever were either starving or like eating cardboard.  The pork chop was definitely disappointing.  It was dry and tough to cut.  I also thought the demi glace that came with it was nasty.  The "smashed potatoes" were homemade hash browns.  If you want a good pork chop try NOPA or even Hillstone.  The pork chop here was disgusting.  My sexy woman ordered the seafood risotto.  It was delicious.  Definitely the best dish of the night.  The waitress gave us the stink eye because we didnt order their signature chocolate bread pudding dessert.  She can kiss my brown eye.
author: Fatty A.

description: After years of my sister raving to me about Frascati, she finally took us there a couple weeks ago.  I was a little worried that she had pumped it up too much, but she was right.  This place IS good.  We started off with a few appetizers:  brussels sprouts and a bruschetta-type dish that had figs (I don't remember what it was called) which were all amazing.  For an entree, I had the pork chops which were incredibly tasty and cooked to perfection.  It was brined very well but after awhile, to me it became a little on the salty side, but that's why it's great to go with people you can share with!  The bread pudding was good but not as good as I was expecting it to be.
author: Amy W.

description: Delicious scallops and steak (me and my husband) and our friend had the bread salad--she enjoyed that too.  Good show!
author: Becky M.

description: A delicious way to end my stay at San Fran!  Very romantic little restaurant nestled in a cozy quiet neighborhood.  DO order the duck confit salad that fellow yelpers have raved about. Was NOT disappointed and rather delighted that it exceeded expectations.  I do warn that it can be a bit heavy for a "salad" but very mindblowingly satisfying.  Skip the octopus salad and order another duck confit salad.  DO order the roasted half chicken.  So moist and juicy inside, with a nice crispy, well seasoned skin outside.  Skip the halibut which was lukewarm maybe due to the temperature of the beets that were beneath the fish.  Also needed some additional seasoning.  We also ordered a side of ratatouille which was very comforting, especially with my chicken. Paired with glasses of white wine and excellent customer service, a very memorable dinner.
author: Nancy S.

description:
pros:
- the service is AMAZING
- dessert! esp. the hazelnut ice cream... mmm
- a bitchin wine list
- black mission figs w/ blue cheese and prosciutto appetizer
- gnocchi, peas, and leek w/ truffle appetizer
- warm, cozy neighborhood feel

cons:
- parking and construction. none of one, lots of the other. respectively. take a cab.
- my prehistoric sized pork chop looked great coming out, but as i cut into it, i saw that about a centimeter was pink, raw and translucent. the color of pickled ginger. eww. sent it back and they re-cooked it, but i was traumatized and didn't touch it after that.
- while the atmosphere and service were great, i find it tough to say that the food was worth the price. just my opinion.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
I wanted to love this place so much, I really did. The location, the windows, the reviews, the neighborhoody feel- all of these components seemed like part of a perfect recipe for a new date spot and a out-of-towners restaurant recommendation, but last night, my hopes were just that: hopes. 

We were 2 couples, with one of the couples being out-of-towners, so we thought a cozy nook like this where they can see the street car go by would be perfect. We were seated upstairs in the back, which would have been great if we wanted a quiet romantic dinner, but as a group we felt isolated from the action and could not see the hustle and bustle of the street. 

The service was about average- attentive and informative, what you would expect.

We started with the gnocchi- one of the recommendations from server. The aromas and colors were tantalizing- but there was no flavor in the perfectly cooked gnocchi. Maybe some garlic, salt, pepper- something was missing in the sauce and I felt like continuing to eat this dish was basically a waste of stomach space. The boys also shared the appetizer special for the evening- the pork terrine. Neither raved about it. 

I had the Roasted Chicken- juicy on the inside, crispy skin on the outside, served with fingerling potatoes, onions, and artichokes. It was yummy and large portions, but I kept thinking to myself that I could pay $8 at Whole Foods or the Farmers Market to get this same chicken (rotisserie-yum!) versus this $26 chicken. So, although my stomach was satisfied, my conscious was not. The other entrees ordered included the pork chop and steak. The presentation of the pork chop was spectacular with the perfect grill marks. However, the tomato-y sauce served with it was an odd combination. 

The two perks of the experience was the wine list and dessert- our Apple Cobbler was warm and gooey served with a large vanilla scoop of ice cream- I guess I could have had just wine and dessert and would have been a happy camper! 

Our total bill was well over $300 (3 apps, 4 entrees, 2 bottles of wine, 2 after dinner drinks)- and although still a pleasant evening, I don't think I would go back to Frescati, no matter how much I wanted to love it.
author: Rena Z.

description: The place to go when friends or family are in town and you want to treat them well. We were not drinking that night and one of us is a vegetarian. The wait staff did not object at all to our limitations. Would definitely keep in on the list for special nights out.
author: joan b.

description:
Cute restaurant, great atmosphere, good food. 

Why four stars you ask? I was more than eager to give this place five but the waiter put me off. He was little "too much" of everything. I understand you want to promote your restaurant but don't be over the top about it. Enough said about him. 

On to bigger and better things - like the rest of my dining experience. We were sitting upstairs so I could see right into the kitchen which was really cool. I started with the risotto which was delicious and probably the best risotto I have ever had! Then I had some amazing chicken. Everyone at my table loved everything they had. The prices were reasonable as well! 

Another great thing - if you bring one bottle and buy one from their list they wave the cork age fee of the first one!
author: Jessica K.

description:
1 word: Duck       2 words: potato gnocchi      3 words: Chocolate Bread Pudding.     4 words:  Off the hook restaurant!!

Done and done.  Do it.  Now.  You wont be dissappointed.  Wait staff, front of house staff, owner, and the mouth watering food.... are all a delight.
author: Vince C.

description:
I was feeling a little down and called a friend to join me for a late night meal.  I had never heard of this restaurant but she had.  I picked her up, drove to Russian Hill and spent a good 20 minutes driving around for a parking spot.  I was immediately worried.

Howerver, once we were seated and greeted by our witty waiter, my reservations  were a thing of the past.  The waiter took the time to educate us on the various dishes and specials, guiding us like a Himalayan sherpa on our first trek.  He was remarkable.

The ambiance was perfect, the wait staff attentive and the food was delicious.  My dining partner and I each had several glasses of wine recommended by our waiter which were well paired with our meals.

The total bill came to about $180 for appetizers, entrees, 3 glasses of wine each, and dessert.

My only complaint is that they didn't have a valet or easy parking, otherwise the resatuarant would have received 5 stars.
author: Dennis M.

description:
This place is a real class operation.  Not only is their food good every time, they make it a point to call me by name.  I have been there probably 10 times and I have never had a bad experience.  I  have sent a dish back once.  It was the hangar steak.  It had a predominate piece of sinew in it.  Not being a fan of chewing on anything other than steak and maybe a little fat I mentioned it to the server.  They handled it immediately.  Once, my date didn't finish all of her lemon chicken.  The server asked her if she liked the chicken.  She said that she didn't.  Without saying anything, the server removed the item from the bill.  I even went with a buddy who has a ton of food allergies they were able to accommodate.

EAT HERE!
author: Greg C.

description:
I was treated to dinner here for my birthday. I'd never heard of the place, but mmmm, what a great experience all around. 

Best qualities: 
Extremely romantic and cozy
Personable but respectful service
Delicious food full of tantalizing flavor combos

We particularly loved the duck confit salad and when our server accepted the invitation to try the Spanish wine we'd ordered.
author: Michael M.

description:
Something about a place that makes you feel welcome right from the get-go. I was greeted by the manager, then several servers, the bartenders, the chefs and pretty much everyone else you can think of in this joint. 

The salad was great, the chicken I got was awesome and I had no room for dessert as you can imagine. And the best part was I didn't feel like I'd just gorged down 800 million calories worth of anything. The food was 'light'. 

Service is a little sluggish, but when you're wining, it doesn't really matter. 

I'd strongly recommend this place.
author: Anand I.

description:
went back for the lamb last night and again, no disappointment, it was juicylicious! I had been raving about Frascati and I wanted to take my lil sis for her last night in SF, mom was there too.

We started with the Foie Gras and Gnocchi once more, but we also gave the Risotto  ($12) a chance.

Next time, no Gnocchi, risotto please. (fois gras, always ;)

the Cobbler was blueberry and peach... warm with the vanilla bean ice cream, warm and cold... warm warm warm get the picture?
author: Diana R.

description:
If half stars were allowed, I'd give Frascati 3.5 stars.

We started with the Summer Corn Risotto which was simply delicious. I loved the sweetness of the corn, and the slightly crunchy texture that it added to the delightfully creamy risotto. The chanterelles were a heavenly addition.

For my main, I had the Maple Leaf Duck Breast with Herb Spaetzle. This dish was almost perfect. There were two pieces of duck breast on my plate. One was deliciously rare, skinless and (dare I say) perfectly cooked in my opinion. The other, however, was a thinner cut with the skin on. The meat was overcooked (medium-well) and part of the skin even appeared almost burnt. Perhaps they do this to appeal to different palates, or to show the versatility of the meat...or maybe it was a mistake? Who knows. If ever I return and order the duck again, I will most definitely ask for both pieces to be rare and juicy. 

My dining partner ordered the halibut which we both found to be bland and slightly on the dry side. Unfortunately I can't say much else about it though except that it wasn't the least bit memorable.
author: Kristen C.

description:
Are there words to describe the fantasticness that is Frascati? No, I don't believe there are.

Sit upstairs away from everyone else and with someone you love or want to woo. Drink wine over candlelight, eat food that is love in edible form, swoon over the chocolate bread pudding. Be amazed.

Or sit downstairs where it's a little louder, and share this delicious food with friends. 

It's a beautiful thing!
author: Christi P.

description: Came here on a Thursday night with the hubby and friends.  We couldn't get a table through open table, so I called the restaurant directly. The guy who picked up was nice enough to squeeze us in, so our night already started off great! We sat upstairs in a small room, so it kind of felt like a semi-private dinner. :). The server brought us bread and olive oil, which i love, but the bread was cold and tasted a little old.  I ordered the pork chop and the hubby ordered the monk fish. The pork chop was a little burnt, but it was still very tasty! I love their sauces! The side potatoes were also very good!  The monk fish was a little plain, and not very filling, but he still enjoyed it.  At the end of dinner, we ordered two desserts, but they were both disappointing.  Im a big dessert fan...so that, plus the cold tasteless bread, knocked them down to 4 stars.  Overall, the service was great, the food was delicious and I will definitely go back!
author: Melissa T.

description: I went there a couple months ago for dinner with a business partner, a SF local, and we both LOVED our meals. The wine selection is a bit lean, but adequate, the meal was superb and I can't wait to go again.
author: Kimberly O.

description: Solid haute cuisine, if expensive, but it really served the purpose of the "special night out" that I picked it for. The food wasn't quite a home run (but close), the location was convenient (at a cable car stop) and the atmosphere was sophisticated but unassuming. I would definitely recommend it to friends.
author: Chris D.

description:
Frascati was our favorite dining experience in San Fran, and it wasn't even close. The atmosphere is perfect for a date, and the servers were very friendly and helpful.

The gnocchi appetizer was one the best things we've ever tasted. We lamented that it wasn't an entree; it was that good. My wife had the pork chop, which was as advertised. I had a white bass dish, which I loved. They prepare everything with simple flavors that always seem to work together perfectly. We finished with the chocolate bread pudding, and it was the perfect way to end - not too rich - and the house made ice cream on top was awesome.

In short, make this place a must eat. We are looking for any excuse to get back there someday.
author: Kyle Y.

description:
I love Frascati -- I've eaten there 4-5 times in the past 6 months or so, and I always come away very happy.  The bread salad is a must-have, as is the chocolate bread pudding (split it, unless you're REALLY hungry -- doubtful at the end of a meal here).  The rabbit salad and the lamb entree were also memorably good.  The service is always friendly but professional, and the wine list is reasonable but interesting.

Don't drive there -- trying to find parking could ruin an otherwise lovely experience.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Too crowded, strange bathroom location.
I've eaten in the front area, and the back room.
Service is good, but usually slow.
author: Tom S.

description:
We had a great night and a great dinner at Frascati on a recen Saturday night. The staff was super-attentive and very knowledgeable about the menu and winelist.  We took our waiter's recommendations on everything and couldn't have been happier with the results.  

We started with the gnocchi and bread salad and both were great. I highly recommend the gnocchi.  It's not smothered in cream sauce like a lot of places and is perfect.  The porkchops with the apple salsa were awesome and the potatoes were top notch.  My wife had the duck which was also very good.  Although I thought my chops were much better.  We ended up just getting wine by the glass, but the house wines were all very good.  I didn't spend much time looking at the entire winelist, but they seem to have a decent selection.

All said and done, Frascati was a great choice.  It's casual and elegant at the same time, and has that nice cozy feel of a Russian Hill neighborhod bistro.  Definitely good for a romantic date, or dinner for 4...I wouldn't go over that number as this is not a good place for a group dinner.  The one downside is parking, so save yourself the trouble and cab it.
author: Bryan B.

description:
"It's one of my favorites!"
"I met my [insert title of significant other] there!"
"I can recite the menu in my sleep!"
"I had my rehearsal dinner there!"

When asking people about Frascati, I received all of these answers within a week.  Thus, the restaurant had high standards to live up to when I showed up for a semi-celebratory dinner on Monday night.  

The location was cute, the staff friendly, and the service impeccable.  They gladly brought me a vase for the huge sunflowers I walked in with (thanks babe) and didn't rush us on menu decisions.  Good wine, excellent watermelon salad with mint, mouthwatering gnocchi, and good duck.  I say "good duck" because I don't really eat duck.  Therefore, it was probably great duck.

I'll be back for the black and white bread pudding when I save more room for dessert.

Frascati has studied up on what it takes to keep up a successful, friendly neighborhood restaurant.  I just wrote the phone # on my day planner under "frequented restaurants."
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
The people I was dining with were 20 minutes late, but the guy seating everyone was very patient, and sat us as soon as everyone arrived. There was no attitude or anything, which was greatly appreciated.

I had the Filet Mignon, which was absolutely delicious, and I'm usually a vegetarian!

If you're looking for pasta dishes, this place doesn't have them. That was my one, big, disappointment.
author: Raymond C.

description:
Frascati is definitely my favorite SF restaurant, by far. I have been three times in the 5 months I have lived here, and each time it has been lovely. 

The atmosphere is great - cozy, dimly lit, not too loud (unless you're sitting next to a really loud party of 6, as we were last time). Service is friendly, helpful and seamless. Prices are pretty decent , especially for this area of town and the quality of the experience. My husband claims the roast chicken is the best he's ever had, and I would agree. I have had the diver scallops and the monkfish (a special). Both are excellent. Also had the gnocchi appetizer, which was scrumptious.

And believe the hype about the chocolate bread pudding. I can pretty much take or leave dessert, but a friend insisted I try it. I will insist the same. Awesome. I will be back as often as possible. The only drawback is the fact it's so tough to get a reservation at a normal time.
author: Erin B.

description:
cozy neighborhood spot with plenty o' action.

who knew?

in a small and quiet part of nob hill, this place was jammin' with young and older couples all in the pursuit of happiness.  for foodies anyways.

cozy = small and tight quarters.  even the bathroom required a pivot er, do your business, and a pivot to wash your hands.  step 3: suck in stomach to open door.

definitely wait for a table upstairs!  you can watch all the action in the kitchen down below.

we were surprised that there was a wait for 7:15 rezzies on a sunday.  i wanted to bribe the people with the asparagus with poached duck egg app at the bar 5$ for a bite.  i wonder if they noticed my drool.

but we were seated about 20 mins after...thankfully, their pours are a decent size.  maybe not the finest selection of wines, but they were quite affordable.

the grilled sardines were so tasty.  light and tiny bones - i could munch on these but if you don't like bones, these are a decent size and you can savor the flaky bits.  it came with a herb salad, lemon aioli and grilled ciabatta bread.

the watermelon salad was so refreshing.  the sweetness was set off with the balsamic vinegar and bits of pistachio and mint.  

the special artichoke salad was so-so.  lots of hearts with fava beans and sea beans - cactus like, with some citrus and herbs against an herb salad.

the strip steak was wafting up to the second floor.  a delectable brown butter and garlic prep with blue cheese.  grilled bread soaked in olive oil and herbs with fresh heirloom tomatos, onions, and citrus was heavenly.

the pork chop was solid with a caramelized white peach and frisse with mizuna, spiced plum, and a cipollini jus.

and if that was too much, save a wee bit of room for a light but tasty panna cotta with caramelized banana.  creamy and deelish!

the bill came with bits of almond rocha.

all in all, the service was friendly and varied.  the bartender was doing double duty.  it looked like we had two waiters.  but who cares?  as long as the food and wine was flowing...you can be bill, jack or harry.

cheers!
author: Anh V.

description: The atmosphere great. Food good. Service decent. I would go back. I had octopus salad and duck.  Both were good. Not over the top excited, but very good stuff.  I heard very good things about this place so that maybe why I was not ecstatic when I left there.
author: Bryan A.

description: Although the food was very good there is just something about this place that didn't make me totally love it.  I think the reason is that i felt so cramped in this place.  It is so tightly packed i felt like a sardine.  There isn't any ambiance in this place besides that it is a cozy neighborhood restaurant.  We went on a Friday night and maybe that was it.  It was just so loud in there, definately not a romantic date place.  However the food was good.  I have to say that.  I'm not hating on it like I said food was good but i think  I just needed a little more space.
author: C Y.

description: Returned after a year or so with some friends. Friendly host and server.  A very good meal, but less than the 5 stars in my last review.  The roast chicken was quite different than the previous visit, and, frankly, disappointing.  Gnocchi was very good, as was the risotto.  Filet Mignon well-prepared, but somewhat thin for $30.  Location is about perfect.
author: John K.

description:
can you pick up the f-ing phone please.  i was running late but had to about kill myself to get their on time because i called 15 times and no one decided to pick up the phone.  how - exactly - is that possible?  do they not have employees there?  no.  i showed up and teh place was full of employees.  do they ignore the phone?  can't one of the waiters pick it up if the hostess or owner is not there.  and it's not like it happened once or twice or it just happened over a 5 minute period while someone was in the can.  i called 15 times over a 30 minute period and they could have been responsible for my death!  

anyway, duck was good.  one piece had the skin the other didn't.  figs were good in their thick sauce.  pear salad had too many pears and i'd skip it in the future.  petite sirah tasted like a pinot.
author: dan h.

description: Amazingly delicious, well prepared food.  Impeccable service and nice ambiance.
author: Jason T.

description: Frascati is a quaint restaurant with deliciously fresh food.  Their homemade pasta tastes delicious and their wine list is lovely.  I definitely recommend if in the area.
author: Charlotte M.

description: Wonderful local Italian place in Russian/Nob Hill. Romantic atmosphere with caring staff, combined with good fare, makes it a consistently positive experience.
author: David A.

description:
I've eaten at Frascati about half a dozen times in as many months.  I've never been disappointed.  It's a terrific neighborhood restaurant for the local crowd, but if I didn't live in the neighborhood, I would still make the trip.  

It's my kind of date place.  Frascati is elagent yet simple as well as small yet comfortable (despite the very close proximity of other tables).  

The food is (or has been) very well prepared, good quality produce and meats, well plated (simple, which is how it should be), the wines are of good quality and selection. 

On a nice night, sitting outside (only 3-4 tables outside) on Hyde Street is great for people watching (assuming your date isn't keeping your attention).  Sat outside on Saturday night with a couple of friends and (much to all of our surprise) there was no wind! (the wind up Green Street is notorious for spoiling an otherwise beautiful day or night).

Try the Tokaji for an after dinner drink.

Would I go again?  Definitely.
author: Arif R.

description: We ventured here on a whim from out of town.  We didn't have to wait and were immediately seated in the upstairs alcove.   The atmosphere was highly romantic and intimate, and the food was sublime (and we're picky).
author: D. L.

description: This place is fantastic! My girlfriend and I ordered the wild mushroom bruschetta, filet mignon, maple duck breasts, apple crisp, and chocolate bread pudding. Each dish was some of the "best  _____" we've had in SF. It's obvious the chefs put a lot of time into perfecting their dishes and it certainly shows. The ambience is great and the service is exceptional. We spent the whole next day saying "oh my god, that was so good!" We cannot wait to go back!
author: Peter J.

description:
What I remember of eating here was amazing.

The service was great and so was the food. I had a spicy pesto pasta, and the foie gras both of which were amazing. This was not the first stop of the night for me so how I got there and how I got back home is a liiiittttle fuzzy but I distinctly remember being blown away by the food and the service.

Met the owner (one of the owners?) John while there and he was nothing but courteous and helpful.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Nick E.

description: Perfect neighborhood date spot. Fabulous Italian food. Most romantic restaurant in the city. Love.
author: Makenna S.

description:
Certainly the best pork chop I've ever had. Out of this world. In addition, the waiter's recommendations were very good (including the pork chop). Chicken was also good but not as good as the pork.

When asked to describe the three entrees I was considering, the waiter only got to the pork chop. While he never stated anything to the effect of "you should get the pork chop," it was clear he had much passion for this particular entree, such enthusiasm that I never heard about the other dishes. He was quite right.
author: erik l.

description:
went here on valentine's day and loved it. i think it might tie for first place on my list of favorite restaurants in sf. 

every bite i took i would just savor...for minutes... with a goofy look on my face. 

and to top it off, the service was excellent. the couple next to us, when asked by the host how his meal was, jokingly made a comment about that only thing he could complain about was getting only one miniature eclair with his dessert... and the host immediately agreed and brought him a second one. 

bring someone special- it'll be a meal to remember.
author: Lindsey H.

description: Great upscale neighborhood restaurant! Went there with four people (including two foodies), and everyone really enjoyed their meals. The highlights were the apple pie, the to-die-for panna cotta with caramelized bananas, and the salmon with pea puree. The only downsides were that the branzino--while very tasty-- was somewhat overcooked, and the octopus in the grilled octopus salad was pretty tough and rubbery. A little pricey, but a great experience.
author: Jenna W.

description:
The restaurant was full when we went on a Saturday night and, even if we had a reservation, we were seated in a little corner by a window and the staircase.  It was very dark and super noisy, then it got really hot up there.  It was so dark I had trouble seeing what was on my plate.

The bathroom:  only 1 and super tiny.

The service was very kind and attentive.  Other than the tea.  I ordered tea and received it but the waiter never came back to give me more hot water.  When I asked for more hot water, I did get just that.  Hot water with the same soggy tea bag I had been using for the past hour and I was expected to reuse my dirty cup as well...

The food was very elaborate, not just one ingredients, but several for each dish, with not really a link between them.
We had the tagliette with red sauce and we had to send it back as it was just salt, so very salty.
The halibut was nice on top of fregola but it was salty as well.
The gnocchi was decent.

For the price, the difficulty in finding parking and the noiseness of the place, we won't be going back.
author: Sailing A.

description:
I came here with my husband on a Saturday night, and loved the ambiance in this tiny restaurant!  We sat on the balcony overlooking the kitchen, and though it got rather "cozy" (i.e. HOT), it was interesting to watch the chefs in action.

I got the tomato basil leek soup, and a gorgonzola pear salad, and my husband got the double stuffed pork chop.  Everything was very good, though nothing really stood out.  Including a few glasses of wine, the bill came to about $120, which wasn't terrible but paying nearly $20 for soup and salad chafed me a bit.  I will definitely be back when I'm really hungry and feel like dropping some money!
author: Alison P.

description:
The first couple of times we dined here I couldn't get enough of the atmosphere, the friendly service, and specifically: the smoked trout salad.  And the chocolate bread pudding.  however, our last two trips I have left slightly underwhelmed...the food wasn't bad; the service was still good. But it just wasn't living up to our initial visits.  And then they took the smoked trout salad off the menu.  Boo.

So here is my ranking of the Hyde Street three: 1550 Hyde on top, then luella, then Frascati.  You really can't go wrong with any of them and that's the beauty of San Francisco.
author: Amy K.

description:
Shared last Sunday evening here with my bride for our 14th anniv. (She found via OpenTable.) After having read many favorable reviews we decided to give it a go. We were pleasantly surprised to see this neighborhood eatery so hoppin' on a foggy Sunday night. Parking in the area is difficult. But I'd rubbed my plastic parking Jesus after dropping off my bride at the corner, and luckily found a street spot only 1.5 blocks away in less then 10mins.

The restaurant itself is very neighborhood chic--elegant, modern, but not too pretentious. The wait staff was attentive without being around too much.

To start, my wife had the frisee salad with poached egg and crispy pancetta--anyway you get bacon & eggs into a salad is fine by me! Since I was ordering the lamb, our waiter suggested the gnocchi appetizer would make the perfect setup. I took his advice, and at the last second requested chef to use only a little truffle oil. Boy! Was I glad I made that request! Past experience has show that truffle oil can overpower EVERYTHING. And when I walked in the restaurant, that was the 1st smell to hit my nose.

The gnocchi were perfect! Tender little pillows of potato pasta with a perfect assortment of garden veggies (fava beans, spring peas, leeks, tomatoes, chervil, garlic) combined with the lightest touch of truffle oil was amazing. We did lick the plate clean!

For our mains: Hers was the blue-nose sea bass with clams, mussels, shrimp and Spanish chorizo. In her words: The best seafood stew possible.

Mine was the rack of lamb--two perfect double-thick chops encrusted in herbs served over potato cream and ratatouille. All dishes paired beautifully to the '05 Honig N.V. Cab Sauv. we brought for our celebration.

A delightful experience I would recommend to my foodie friends and will try to make it back again soon. Excellent food with perfect service!
author: Daryl B.

description: Stay away from this restaurant if you want to have an enjoyable meal.  The waitstaff were incredibly rude and the main course took forever to come.  But the worst thing was that I ordered the duck done medium and specifically asked the waiter to be careful to make sure it isn't rare, since I'm pregnant.  Unfortunately, the duck showed up completely rare and I had to send it back (once I finally got the waiter's attention b/c he was giving us really bad service).  When it came back a second time, it was still pretty red, so we paid our bill and left without eating, after which the manager did some questionable things and was surprisingly rude.  I would stay as far away from this restaurant as possible, and I hardly ever say that about a place, since I eat out practically every night.
author: Sonia A.

description:
Service is great

Appetizers: Duck Confit Salad - A MUST, this was great!
                     Foie Gras - pretty good. 

Main Course: Branzino is very good but I thought the tapenade it came with was a little too creamy.

Halibut - this was my favorite. It was in a spicy tomato broth that brought out the flavor of the fish. 

Dessert: Definitely get the chocolate bread pudding with the hazelnut ice cream. The bread pudding is a little heavy but goes great with the ice cream.
author: blahblah h.

description: I'm going to try not to gush too much! This little gem was outstanding. We sat outside at a sidewalk table because the weather was lovely. Started with the potato gnoochi in white truffle oil which was amazing. Then tried the chilled peach basil soup which was unique and very refreshing. For the main course I had the sturgeon which comes with some ravioli... Very succulent and flavorful. My husband and I shared the chocolate bread pudding which totally blew me away! To top it off our waitress was delightful!
author: Dianne C.

description: I've eaten here a few times sometimes for special occassions: it's one of my favorite San Francisco places. Sometimes it's too crowded and noisy for my taste but I go on off times or early. Food is consistently very good, service has been quite good. Don't plan on parking nearby. Don't sit upstairs: did once and the smoke and fumes from the kitchen made my eyes water. One Valentines Day they arranged for a vase of roses my partner ordered to be on the table. Quite sweetly accomodating. (He hasn't done that since ... hmpf!). Frascati probably isn't the best SF restaurant but its quite a good, special local neighborhood place  to go one a regular basis for great food.
author: Richard A.

description: The food was simply great.  You must try the porkchops -  I'm not even much of a meat eater, and I agreed that my boyfriend's dish was nothing short of amazing.  And my scallops were really wonderful too.  Nice ambiance for a quiet, romantic dinner.  Best meal I've had in SF so far!
author: Alisa B.

description: What a lovely local treasure ... Seated when we arrived.  I had the octopus salad, excellent, and the duck ... even better.  My lady have the pear salad and the Pesto Linguini with sea food, also excellent. We were celebrating her birthday and to our surprise and delight a complementary dessert was delivered.  Staff was very pleasant ... small and intimate venue ... not super quite but what would you expect in a hopping restaurant?
author: Howard B.

description: I had this place book marked for months before trying it. The ambiance and service were great, but the food was mediocre especially for the price.
author: Megan P.

description: This place was perfect! The location is quaint and charming. It is busy every night so you should make a reservation. We started with the gnocchi with asparagus, peas and a brown butter sauce. They were just melt in your mouth. I had the chicken that was extremely juicy with a crispy skin on top of pearl onion, artichoke hearts, spinach and fingerling potatoes. My boyfriend had the pork chop. It was cooked perfectly with an amazing rich tomato sauce and spring veggies. I will be back for sure. Our bill was $100 for 2 glasses of wine 1 appetizer 2 entrees 1 dessert and 2 coffees. Which felt like a steal!!! So good!
author: Chelsea C.

description: I had a wonderful birthday dinner here last month and am just now getting around to writing the review.  Every detail of the dinner was perfect.  We especially liked the cheese plate appetizer and peach and blueberry crumble dessert.
author: Marienna M.

description: Very enjoyable restaurant.  Food and service were both excellent.  Cute neighborhood place.
author: Steven R.

description:
It was unexpectedly a gorgeous Wednesday night in the city.  Just a few days ago the fog was so thick that sitting outside would not be appealing.  But since there was a bit of a wait for a table inside, we were offered to sit outside on the sidewalk.  There was no patio area, which at first seemed a bit odd to have a table out in the middle of a sidewalk with no other tables around it... but I was definitely the minority vote.  My friends said that it is rare to have a warm beautiful night... so of course we took full advantage of it by dining outside.  And I'm so glad we did because it really was gorgeous out.  And it was pretty cool when the cable car would pass by.
We probably had 5 different servers that night... and they were all so friendly and attentive.  We had appetizers that we shared... honestly am blanking out on their names... anyway it was delicious.  I ordered what the waiter suggested, pork chop entree which apparently paired well with the pinot noir that I was drinking.  I also tasted the scallops and the chicken entrees which were both amazing. I believe they change their menu daily.  I always like that, because it just makes me want to come back.  Unfortunately, we all passed on dessert since it was getting so late.
author: Myra M.

description: This is a true gem in the heart of Russian Hill.  We came here for my birthday a few months ago and it was a wonderful experience.  The service was fantastic, the food and the wine and the ambiance were completely wonderful.  I don't remember exactly what I had but I remember thinking it was fabulous...the wine must have done its job that night!  Lovely spot that makes me appreciate this city.
author: Nilu r.

description:
So yummy! Had a great dinner last night. Service was friendly and attentive. Atmosphere is really cozy and sweet.

We LOVED the special burrata app, the gnocchi (so absolutely delicious), the roast chicken, and the amazing bread pudding topped with a dynamite home-made hazelnut ice cream. The only dish we weren't enthralled with was the grilled bread salad. It was good, but didn't meet the bar set by the other dishes. 

I soooooo look forward to returning!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Great restaurant. We had the watermelon triangles in a balsamic reduction with goat cheese, pistachios and mint, definitely one of the best, and also most interesting appetizers I've ever had. 

The service wasn't absolutely fabulous, but the atmosphere and food were amazing. This is my "Firefly" of Nob Hill.
author: Melissa M.

description:
I heard a lot of really good things about this restaurant so when my friend came into town from Miami I knew exactly where to take him. 

BAD CHOICE!!

The server was great but the food was seriously sub-par. Had the gnocchi, torchon, and lobster risotto as starters. No flavor what so ever!! The risotto was way under cooked, the gnocchis were over worked, and the torchon had no flavor (not to mention the brioche was burnt and stale.

For entrees my friend ordered the rigatoni, his girlfriend ordered the monkfish (which they subbed swordfish for... really?) and I had the redfish. Again no seperation of flavor at all!!!!! The skin on my fish was torn and looked like shit, the swordfish was hammered and the rigatoni was wat under cooked also and tasted like something we would eat as staff meal at the restaurant I work at.

I don't think I'll be wasting my time with this joint again.
author: Dave U.

description:
I had heard great things, and overall it was a nice experience but a little disappointing.

I went with my family (who were in town visiting) and the service was soooooo sloooooooooow. It took about 1/2 hour after our entree was cleared for a after dinner coffee to arrive. And then another 20 to get our check.

That aside, the food was good (chicken not the greatest), and the atmosphere is really cosy.

I'd still go again, and just hope for the service to improve.
author: Danielle A.

description:
Very picturesque, quaint corner spot on Hyde St.  Delicious food.

Try the Black Mission figs with goat cheese, prosciutto and balsamic 
Also, the Heirloom Tomato Salad with basil and ricotta and the Maple Leaf Duck breast. 

Great wine list.

Difficult to get in, ALWAYS busy, so try to get a res.

Clearly, this is not an easy neighborhood to find parking in, so plan accordingly.  There are massive amounts of cabs in the area.  No need to give a restaurant one star if you haven't even tried it.
author: Brenna C.

description: Everything is excellent. Most unexpected desert of the year goes to Frascati's basil ice cream. You have to try it!
author: Russell C.

description: Service left a lot to be desired, food was decent but have had better. Will give it one more shot.
author: Christie S.

description: The fact that Frascati is only 3 blocks away from our home makes this place is special to us. We love the enviroment, the food, the servers, the bartender all super stars!!!
author: Ty N.

description: Excellent service lovely home like room able to  converse.
author: Nella S.

description: YUM! My friend took me here for my birthday after listening to co-workers rave about it. We were not disappointed. The roasted chicken was fabulous and I loved the gnocchi and cheese stuffed pan roasted figs as well.  The black and white bread pudding was a great end to the night. The service was excellent and the ambiance is great. Cannot wait to return and try the rest of the menu after I recover from my food comma!
author: Amanda H.

description: I have eaten here several times and it is always terrific.  Be sure to get the gnocchi, for desert the bread pudding is one of the best I have ever had.
author: Jay C.

description: so good! this place is so cute, we had a glass of wine down at the bar while we were waiting and were seated upstairs, which was so cozy- looked like someone's living room. my boyfriend did not stop exclaiming during his entire meal- he got a steak. Every bit of it was perfect. I got the half chicken, which was also perfect. We split an apple cobbler. The entire experience- the food, the service, and the atmosphere was wonderful.
author: Alexandra F.

description: Pretty good, but I wasn't blown away.  Nice for a date.
author: jay w.

description:
A wonderful neighborhood restaurant that non neighborhood folks find delightful, delicious and worth visiting more than once. The chef, Max Di Mare is an up and coming wonder that has been written up in the paper and deserves all the recognition he gets.
Lovely food with unique flavors, a wait staff that just can't do enough for you, and a wine list that will tickle your toes.  Tony Manhattan will help you pick your wines, and you won't be sorry.
If there was a six star category, Frascati would have it.
Nancy Ballard
author: Nancy B.

description:
Get the chicken, whatever you do, get the chicken. It is  the most perfect chicken you will ever taste ( notice my seriousity). It is perfectly soft, yet crisp and flavorful. The gnocci(sp?) was highly reccomended to us, but it was somewhat disspointing. The salads are all excellent, as are the homemade sorbets, and really, all the desserts. The veggy/cream soup we had was tasty and reminded me of a butternut squash soup i'd tasted in oaxaca oddly enough. or maybe its not odd. i don't know.
This is one of the best italian resturants in the city, and remember, always get the chicken.
author: Holly Golighty M.

description: We've been meaning to get here for months after hearing great things about it. Frascati is so cute and welcoming upon arrival. There are many quiet and cozy spaces throughout the restaurant to enjoy their delicious food! The mushroom brochette and burrata were filled with layers of flavor. I had the duck, cooked to perfection with fennel and spinach spaetzel. The seafood dishes were also amazing. I really wanted to try the papperdelle and sausage dish, looked amazing. I will definitely be back soon. The service was very professional and friendly but not overbearing. They also have a reasonable and local wine list. Parking isn't ideal but can be done if your are willing to drive around for a little while. We live close, we'll take a cab next time. I really feel that living in SF you pay up for quality food, which I don't mind from time to time. At Frascati, the prices are reasonable for the quality and experience you receive. Highly recommend it!
author: Kate N.

description: We enjoyed our night. Was at the beginning of August. We brought our bottle of Champagne, the french waiter was really nice and helpful in the dishes's choice. With his recommendation, we tried the gnocchi and that was great even if i never liked them before. Very yummy !! The chocolate pudding was so huge that we couldn't finish it, even shared !!! Will definitely go back !!! Excellent restaurant and very tasty food.
author: F T.

description: i am going out on a limb and giving out a 5star review to a restaurant. we went back for date-night and
author: Roger T.

description:
I have to state first off, that this place has fantastic food and the chefs are amazing. My complaint is for the service. This is not the place to go to celebrate a special occasion, as they do not take notice or don't have time to accommodate special requests or occasions. Wonderful food (my husband's favorite meal in the city), service so-so, special occasion location=definitely NOT.
The first time my husband and I ate here it was fabulous but it was for our wedding anniversary and I had asked them for a quiet, romantic table. Coming from a food service background (10+ years) I understand that accommodating special requests isn't always possible, but should be taken into account. So when we were promptly seated (in the empty restaurant at 6:30pm on a Friday) in the very center of the room...I was a bit perturbed. No mention of celebration. Loved the food so decided that even with the lack of concern for guests' wishes or requests on very special occasions, we would return. 
Last week was my birthday. My husband made reservations at Frascati well in advance (noting the special occasion again in the reservation). Again, food was wonderful (especially the clams, the duck and the steak), but no mention of the special occasion. Two strikes doesn't make this place a desirable location for a special celebratory meal...maybe we'll try for a third, but next time we won't be hoping any sort of special treatment.
Go, and enjoy the food, it is wonderful.
author: Katie R.

description:
frascati is truly a neighborhood gem.

we started with the foie gras torchon and the roasted eggplant/tomato bisque.

for my main entree i had the braised short ribs which simply melted in my mouth.  the meat was so damn tender it wasnt even funny.  my wife had the prosciutto wrapped monkfish which was simply wonderful.  the potato-fennel gratin which came with her meal was the perfect compliment to the fish.  

for dessert we had the infamous bread pudding.  

the restaurant is quite cozy and intimate and i highly recommend making reservations especially on friday through sunday nights.  street parking maybe a bit difficult to find although there is a parking garage less than a block away.  really can't wait to return and try the remainder of the menu.
author: Leon C.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I take all my family and friends here when they visit.  The grilled bread salad is delicious and the chocolate bread pudding is divine.
author: J D.

description: What a sexy, grown-up restaurant!  Everything here is just flawless - the flavors are subtle and expertly executed.  This place is made for those intimate conversations where you realize how supremely cool your lover is and how lucky you are to have nights like this.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: Yummy but pricey. Two desserts + two cappucinos + one tea = $30.00!! Great service though and desserts were good... We had the black n white bread pudding with ice cream, and the panacotta, roughly $9 each. Cute place for an intimate date, but be ready for a hefty bill.
author: Mikolo R.

description: Frascati is one of my favorite restaurants in all of northern California.  A friend of mine has lived on Russian Hill for eons, and one day she mentioned to me this great new restaurant that she has discovered around the corner.  Basically, every time I go into the city to see her, we go to Frascati.  Occasionally we break out of our rut and try someplace else, but in the end we always return.  I've probably eaten there over 20 times since whenever it opened, and only once was the experience not perfection, and that was when they refused to serve us mashed potatoes despite all our begging and whining because "they did not have enough potatoes."  (!)  But we forgave them.  Frascati serves delicious, hearty, comforting food cooked to perfection that does not overwhelm you with quantity and grease.  I eat very little red meat, but when some is on the menu at Frascati, it's got my name on it.  When they actually prepare mashed potatoes, they are heavenly.  My friend and I usually split a chocolate bread pudding after we've stuffed ourselves with the main course (generally taking home half of the meat) and by then we are so done you could stick a fork in us.  Frascati is a wonderful, cozy little North Beach/Russian Hill neighborhood bistro, and I highly recommend it.  It's also good for out of town visitors because the surrounding neighborhood is as charming as it gets.
author: Lira K.

description: Really, really good Italian food. The risotto was amazing. Nice wine list. Get a glass of wine at Bacchus Wine Bar across the street while you wait for your table.
author: Aaron E.

description: OK, I may be a little biased as this is my neighborhood place and I love these guys to death.  Everyone that works here is friendly and low-key and just great.  It's cozy and warm and the food is the same - just so satisfying.  I really can't say anything bad: the gnocchi are sublime, the wine list is thoughtful and affordable, the pork chop is one of the best I've had (a far cry from often-dry-and-boring chops, and came with kicky fennel sausage), and we all know about the chocolate bread pudding.  I would only be tempted to knock off half a star for how morbidly obese I feel after leaving here, but it's not their fault that I stuff my face with juicy lamb chops and charcuterie and figs with blue cheese and an entire order of the aforementioned bread pudding with homemade hazelnut ice cream.  It's just not.
author: Melissa B.

description: Living right down the street from this restaurant, it always becomes the go to place when you can't decide where to go. And it always lives up to expectations. Great food, nice ambiance, and a nice wine list. Service is top of the line. No matter what, the truffle gnocchi is a must have.
author: Michael C.

description: Frascati is one of those restaurants that make you love living in SF! I am so bummed that I did not try it sooner. I had dinner with a friend and everything we had was excellent. The half chicken had so much flavor and was soo tender, I am still thinking about it. We also shared two desserts and the, the chocolate bread pudding was to die for!! The place is pretty small and it can be hard to get a reservation, but it is so worth it!! By far, one of the best small restaurants in the city!!
author: Lisa A.

description:
A great recommendation for a family dinner or a romantic date, Frascati's serves up simple ingredients in flavorful, delicious dishes!  The combination is a success in my book.

My plan to surprise my husband with a romantic dinner at Frascati's was a 100% success!  We enjoyed the location, atmosphere, and service.  Located right across a cable car stop, its a charming way to arrive to your dinner.  Close by is a wine bar where you can enjoy a glass of wine, sake, etc. before your reservations.  The venue itself is intimate, with two levels.  For family dinner, chose the lower level.  The upstairs is small, overlooking the kitchen and lower level tables, making your dinner a unique experience.  Our waiter was from our hometown!!!! Small world...

After reading some of the reviews, I agree potato gnocchi is delicious but what stands out for us was the duck confit salad, roasted chicken and porkchop entrees.  Let the wait staff pair your meal with your wine, they do a great job!  Although my husband says 'try', I would skip the bread pudding and hazelnut ice cream pairing.  Maybe venture out and try another desert on the menu?  I felt the night we were there, chocolate pudding was overpowering the gentle hint of hazelnut in our ice cream.

Take a walk around the neighborhood after your meal.  Our 7 pm reservations was a perfect time to catch the sunset after our dinner.
author: Yulia G.

description: Frascati's is delicious. We started with the gnocchi and bread salad. Gnocchi is amazing, perfect little pillows with slight hints of truffle. The bread salad is good, but nothing to write home about...wasn't what I expected. It's basically a Greek salad with softer fresh "croutons" mixed in. It's good, but nothing outrageously special.  We had the duck and the pork chop. The duck had crispy skin and was cooked to a perfect medium rare. The spaetzle was an interesting side that we don't see often with duck and was quite good. The pork chop is perfect. The marinade really soaks into the meat. It's tender and flavorful. Top 3 pork chops I've had. The chocolate bread pudding with their homemade chocolate peanut butter ice cream was amazing. We are hooked and can't wait to bring guests.  We requested a window table, so if you have a special evening, make sure you request that!
author: Erin T.

description: I might actually go with 2.5. I thought the portions were too small - our order of gnocchi was about 2 bites - literally - 2 bites - if that. My swordfish lacked any flavor. My coffee was even sub par. I dont know what to say. I was utterly disappointed and heard this place was great. But I have had much much MUCH better. And our waiter was  ADD - the annoying and not amusing kind.
author: Stacy H.

description: Fantastic food, great atmosphere, and good service.  The stonefruit bruschetta was amazing (although I think it was a special).
author: April W.

description:
UPDATE - 4 STARS
2007

So, one year later, my lady and I returned to the scene of the crime to celebrate her 23rd birthday.  Aside from a few minor menu changes, Frascati was pretty much the same as we'd left it one year earlier.  This time, however, was slightly lackluster compared to the wonderful experience we had on our first trip.  
For appetizers we ordered the duck trio and the seared ahi with spicy fennel salad.  The duck trio was a dish we both remembered very fondly from our first visit, but this time around it completely underwhelmed.  The duck roulettes (a dish we craved for weeks after the first time around) was a bit dry, stringy and quite bland.  The seared ahi was tasty because ahi is always delicious and the fish was great quality, but the preparation lacked flavor and cohesion...the spicy fennel salad tasted like poorly made kim chee or bad cole slaw.  Both dishes we could have lived without.   

For our entrees, I ordered the bass and my beautiful woman ordered the steak.  The blue nose bass came in a delicious saffron-tomato sauce with clams, mussels, shrimp and spanish chorizo.  This was definitely the stand out dish of the night.  The bass was cooked to perfection, with a crisp, tasty outside and a tender, meaty center.  The flat iron steak had a great taste, but was served incredibly rare (the supposed medium-rare preparation was basically just seared on the outside and completely raw in the center).  We asked to have it remade, cooked to medium this time, which they were more than happy to do for us with no trouble.  When it returned, however, it seemed to be cooked exactly the same as the first time.  Not wanting to return the dish a second time (and figuring that was just the way the chef intended), we stuck with it.  Aside from the chewiness of the raw beef in the center, the all around taste was great, we only wished that we could have gotten it prepared to our taste a little more.  
For dessert, we shared the chocolate bread pudding which was yummy, but not much more spectacular than the chocolate lava cakes I get from Trader Joe's for a fraction of the cost.  
All around, we had a great time at Frascati the second time around regardless of the few shortcomings.  Fair warning though, if you're slightly "alternative" looking or a race other than the standard white or asian that usually traverses the wealthy neighborhoods of San Francisco, expect to get stared at a fair amount by snobby diners who probably think you're invading their turf.  Not everyone that dines at Frascati is that way, but don't be surprised if you feel you have to tell some old white lady that you're going to have to start charging a fee if she continues to oggle you.  

----------------------------------------------------

ORIGINAL REVIEW - 5 STARS 
2006
July 31st was my wonderful girlfriend's birthday.  Unfortunately, as things go, we ended up having a really big fight that day.  When i say it was a big fight, I really mean that it was BIG...really bad.  So bad, in fact, that it's hard to imagine that we could have carried on after it, but nonetheless, that night I took her to Frascati, as I'd had planned to for several weeks before hand and regardless of all the negativity, we had an amazing time.  The food was perfect!  
I don't know whether this review is a testament to our incredible relationship or the amazing food at Frascati, but I know that this restaurant will always have a special place in my heart because of that night.  I honestly can't think of a single thing I would have changed about the dinner we had.  It was absolutely perfect.
author: c o.

description: I'd been wanting to try Frascati for over a year, so I finally decided to have the man take me for my birthday, and I could not have been more thrilled with the experience. We walked in a full half hour before our reservation on a busy Saturday night expecting to have a glass of wine at the bar while we waited, only to be seated immediately in a lovely window seat. The service was prompt without being rushed, and our server was incredibly helpful when it came to ordering. We started with the gnocchi with butternut squash and leeks which was incredible, and the steak tartare, which also didn't disappoint. Then I had the duck breast with herb spaetzle and huckleberry sauce - phenomenal - and the man had a bass dish which he thoroughly enjoyed. We weren't going to get dessert since we were so full, but we stayed to digest over another glass of wine. Of course after the fourth glass of the evening, I brilliantly decided that I wanted to blow out a birthday candle. So I ordered the famous chocolate bread pudding which came with a healthy scoop of hazelnut ice cream. Man, I totally understand the hype now. It was so f-ing delicious that despite being completely stuffed, we pretty much licked the plate clean. It was totally worth the wait, but now that it's my new favorite restaurant, you better believe I'll be there often.
author: Victoria L.

description: I really really liked this place.  I went here on a date and it was a great choice!  we were seated upstaira where it was intimate and cozy.  Everything was great.....the wine and my dish.  I actually really loved my dish and my date's dish looked really good as well.  Definitely a place where I would want to try other dishes rather than stick with one.  I live so close and yet don't ever go.  I'm going to try and change that.
